I'll start with our first exceptional or excruciating experience here which was.....(drum roll).....a bit excruciating. Walking into the TINY men's room to wash my hands I'm met by a tall, well-dressed gentleman who confronts met again & again. "Oh brother, I just wanna wash my GD hands!" They STILL have washroom attendants??? It's so ANTIQUATED! What else...white's only tables? Give it up 21 Club!!! Along with your jacket policy. Or we won't be coming back.Now the exceptional. Our server Rob F. was very good...very, very good & the food was pretty good, also. We both ordered off the fixed price menu which had great variety. My husband loved his salmon tartar but my shrimp was over-cooked. We both did however, like the chicken with spaetzle and the lamb bolognese (we share) and our chocolate panna cota and orange tartlet was nice, especially with the very good coffee.They also brought a dessert sampler for my birthday....very sweet.And Rob paid attention to our note in the special request section of the booking engine where I added that we were coming to the 21 Club because we like historic New York. He came to the table and shared some of the 21 Clubs rich history...very RICH.Now for a little more of the excruciating...All through the meal we noticed little specs floating gently down upon us from above. As you can see in any photos of the dining room there are hundreds of toys hanging from the ceiling. They looked very clean! But really, if you do not clean them thoroughly EVERY day with a LIQUID then you're not doing a good and safe job protecting your customers.Who knows how old those specs were and how many of them made their way into our gullets? I say get rid of them. It's disgusting.
Taste of old New York. Loved every part of the experience - great cocktails & food, old male waiters, over the top memorabilia decor on the ceiling!

I had heard good things about this place so I went there for dinner with a friend during Restaurant Week to check it out. While the food itself wasn't bad, the overall ambience was a bit off-putting. A few notes: -Food: The food and drinks were decent--nothing that will blow you away--but decent enough. I stuck with the Restaurant Week menu so perhaps I didn't get the full 21 Club experience, but I figured a specialized menu would showcase at least a few standouts; unfortunately nothing really stood out for me. -Atmosphere: The clientele looked surprisingly diverse. I thought it'd be predominantly musty old men but saw a mixed crowd. Unfortunately for us, we were seated next to some eyeroll-worthy guy who very much liked hearing the sound of his pseudo-European accent and enjoyed unnecessarily flipping his scarf throughout his dessert cheese platter. At one point, we heard this individual ask the waiter about the Restaurant Week crowd. The waiter, perhaps to humor the customer (who clearly fancied himself a regular), said something like, "Yeah, they'll come, order from the Restaurant Week menu, and we won't see them again until the summer [when Restaurant Week returns]," after which they both chuckled. Pretty obnoxious commentary from the waiter and a "regular" (who, by the way, was basically seated in the Solange section of the restaurant #justSaying). -Dress Code: I got scolded for taking my jacket off after we were already seated and had started eating. I understand having a dress code to get in and wanting to create a particular vibe among customers, but you don't need to get your panties in a twist just because a customer is getting overheated.-Bathroom Attendant: The men's bathroom has someone there to "help" you wash your hands, something that I've been doing myself for a few years now and which I had thought was limited to pretentious, overpriced clubs in the Meatpacking District. Overall, I wouldn't return here (not even for Restaurant Week over the summer).

Rude horrible pretentious service.  The person on the phone making the reservation sounds like someone from the 1800s with a snotty rude tone.  That should have been a sign to not visit. Food is nothing spectacular,  over priced menu.  Tourist trap!  Stay away! !

Make sure when you come you read the fine print on their website. It says, "Dress code: Jackets are necessary for gentlemen. Jeans and sneakers are not permitted."So, my party didn't really realize this, and had to walk back to change, it was like 4 degrees weather outside. Yeah, not happy.... but plus side is when we went back, my younger brother, who was visiting and didn't bring a jacket, wasn't turned away, instead they lent him a jacket to wear. The food was alright considering it was the restaurant week's menu. They didn't have a separate menu for restaurant week, instead it was marked with a figure on the side. The whole lay out was really cute and clever. It was just too bad, I couldn't get a picture because I had to walk so long outside, my phone's battery froze (yes, I need a new phone). So, it has been a couple of weeks since my visit, which is most of the case when I actually write my reviews because I want it to settle in before I actually do (any not do anything too rash or too in the heat of the moment, and if something really stands out, it will stay in memory). Anyways, the food didn't really stand out, pretty mediocre, not horrible nor great. The service was alright, they were nice enough to keep our table until we came back almost 45-1 hour later. However, as I have learned after my meal, you can go around and tour around the building. We didn't realize that was an option and plus, the receptionist didn't seem too happy with us being either, he kind of glared at us till we left. So we got out asap. But I really did enjoy the decor on the ceiling in the restaurant. Will I come back? Probably not, if there is no special, the food isn't really worth its original price, nor is the service. But if restaurant week comes around again, and I happen to feel like it, I might give it another try.

Hey if you have 5 $ sign, you better provide good service. Our server Jonathan was really just not there. We had to ask for service every single time instead if him coming to us.I waited 15min for a glass of water after I sat down and they already gave me the bread...( which I don't understand why cuz I hadn't ordered at that time)The food was pretty good though, good value through restaurant week. The decor was food but it's a little dark. My rose wasn't very impressive and they only have one kind. Fun fact: 21 club was the famous speakeasy place back in the days!

Great food. Great service. There is a reason this place is an institution. Amazingly flavorful dishes, great food recommendations by waiter and charming service from everyone from the door man and bathroom attendant to the bus boy, maitre d, and waiters. The cocktails were alarmingly sweet, and perhaps could do with a bit of an update on that menu, but somehow still added to the overall charm and "oldschoolness" of this venue.

I will give ti 4 stars, but I really want to give it 3.5 stars. The service was great. Yes, guys have an attitude, but they are very attentive. The food -- not so special. I had better entrees for half the price. Worth a visit.

Attempted to go for lunch, maitre d' told me that they can't offer service to me because restaurant has a no sneaker dress code. While I respect establishments enforcing dress code, this place needs to update itself with time, it's not 1990 anymore, a pair of python skin Christian Louboutin high-top shouldn't be treated like New Balance. I am happy to spend my money elsewhere that understands and appreciates fashion.

Maybe it was because of RW, but primary waiter was horrible and maitre d disorganized and rude.  Food was also weak - I was embarrassed I brought my client here.  Also, flatly rejected a request to see the wine cellar.  Hey buddy - there's usually a good tip to be had!  Only bright spots were the runners and busboys who were working hard; without them we would've had zero service.

HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE!21 Club is supposed to be an institution in Manhattan but their lackluster food and poor service instantly made me regret coming here for restaurant week lunch. My husband and I arrived 5 minutes early for our reservation and were promptly ignored by an amazingly obnoxious maitre d, that is until 5 minutes had passed at which point he decided to look us up and down (I guess that was his way of assessing whether or not we fit the restaurant's dress code - in hindsight I wish we hand't so we could spend our lunch money elsewhere) and showed us to our table.We were then "greeted" by our waiter who seemed rushed and was quite rude. For the first course I had the crab and salmon tartare. Small portion and FISHY - you could smell it on its way to the table. I forced a bite down before I threw in the towel - I didn't want to risk getting food poisoning. The Short Rib was terribly bland. It was way over cooked, very dry and again of a very small portion. For dessert I had the caramel banana sundae - the only highlight of the meal but really, anyone can make a sundae. The meal and waitstaff both left much to be desired. In summary, 21 Club offers small portions of poor food served by pretentious waiters in a dated atmosphere. I find myself wondering how the 21 Club remains in business but I guess that they capitalize on their reputation.WORST RESTAURANT I'VE BEEN TO IN A LONG TIME. DO NOT RECOMMEND.

I have been here for lunch, dinner, and finally restaurant week. While the history, menu and décor are there, the food is just not 4 star worthy. The price is close to ridiculous for a non-Michelin restaurant. The crowd are generally older upper east side folks who never go outside of the neighborhood to try something better..Most recent experience: - Appetizers: Prawn and salmon tartar are both very good - Main course: braised short rib and chicken are good as well - Dessert: chocolate panna cotta WAS A JOKE, I could've bought it at CVSService is okay, it's not French or Japanese so you get the point.

For many years 21 was our birthday tradition for my daughter, it started many years back when she was 5. The politeness and kindness is the staff from the MD to the ladies room attendant always remarkable. The food constantly good and fresh. Great for a dinner of 2 or a large group, they truly aim to please. The history of the building and the restaurant are still evident today. Lovely place, everyone should get dressed for dinner and experience 21 at least once.

Food at best was just mediocre.  I think for the food we had, it was still over priced for the restaurant week menu. Asked for hot water, and the waiter replied "it will be $5".  Cute place, but there are just way too many other great places to pick than coming here for a mediocre experience.
Tried RW lunch.Service was good.Food was good but not impressive.Interior was unique.Seating was extremely tiny,they pack too many customers at one time

This place's lighting was made for photographing food and then posting it on the Internet. The food itself, for the winter restaurant week, was as good as we anticipated (we'd been eyeing this place for quite some time). The selection was generous--you could have the 21 Club Caesar salad, a prawn, maine crab/salmon tartare (always my choice if its on the menu) or the soup of the day for appetizers, Amish chicken (which I got), salmon, lamb bolognese, or red wine braised short ribs for the entree, and a banana caramel sundae (awesome), chocolate panna cotta, tarte a l'orange, or mixed fruit/berries for the dessert. The appetizer was fresh--the salmon and crab worked well together, though I mostly tasted the salmon and did not seem to get much of the crab. The chicken for my entree was superb, and the sundae was heavenly. I had a great meal here. The only reason this place didn't get 5 stars is because our table felt claustrophobic (compared to the ones next to us, where two people could sit comfortably next to one another on the same side), and the waitstaff was a bit impatient; it was understandable because the place was crowded, and overall they still provided good service. My boyfriend even bonded with one of our waiters over being Greek. The decor on the ceiling was a bit unnerving--it's a distinct collection of random objects, including helmets and toy trucks, that are suspended over your head as you eat. I was a bit paranoid they might fall on me should there be an earthquake or something. But other than that, the place was swanky, the clientele seemed high-class, the general atmosphere felt aristocratic, etc. You cannot come here dressed in jeans and a t-shirt... In fact, it is a jacket-required place for men, and women would do well to dress up for the occasion as well. The bathrooms have attendants (at least, the women's room did), and the coat check was efficient and organized. I look forward to my next visit here.

I really like this place, but I must take one star off for the lady that called to confirm my reservation. The conservation went like this:"What time is your reservation?""Oh, uh, let me check. Hold on."- 2 seconds -The lady begins SHOUTING into the phone "HELLO?!! HELLOOOOOO?!!!!""yes, what?""I AM NOT DONE TALKING!!!!!"I have then decided that I am not inclined to deal with this kind of treatment so I just hung up.The day of the meal:I came for restaurant week. I'd like to believe the food is different during their non-restaurant week times. We were not offered water or the wine menu when we sat down. Our appetizer came in 5 minutes and we were still not asked water -- we had to ask for water when we were done with our appetizers.The salmon tartare was weird..the lemon sauce was so overwhelming -- it was like eating one of those super sour candies. I got the short rib as entree and it's just tasteless overcooked pulled pork. I loved the mashed potatoes and carrots though. I got chocolate pana cotta as dessert and the sauce at the bottom of the dish was way too sweet. What is with this place and proper sauce pairing?!My boyfriend and I ordered wine -- which was great. I enjoyed the service from our waiter, and this is why I'm giving this place a 3 star. Our waiter was patient, and took time explaining the history and figurines when I asked. Summary: food - 2 stars. host/phone person - 0 stars. service - 5 stars.

I visited here for restaurant week as it had been on my list for a while. I really enjoyed the place, the atmosphere and the food. I really appreciated the good service I got here, the doorman, the host taking my coat & the nice lady in the bathroom. From entering the restaurant it felt welcoming, the staff are dressed well and the bar/lounge area was very cosy. Our table wasn't ready straight away so we had a seat at the bar & did some people watching. There was a bit of an older crowd & what looked like business people. When our table was ready the host addresses us by Mr & Mrs and carried out drinks to our table. Once we sat down we took in the decor which is a bit kitsch, which I loved! There were small airplanes and trucks hanging from the ceiling and red checked tablecloths. The food was very good, to start I had crab and salmon tartare and my husband had the head on maya prawn. Both were very tasty & full of flavor, we were very impressed. For our main meal I had the short ribs and my husband the Amish chicken. We ordered French fries to accompany them as we felt we needed some carbs, but afterwards wish we had got vegetables as we were missing them from our dishes. The chicken was a really large chicken breast, but the short ribs portion was on the small side, although it was excellent and again full of flavor, I just would have liked more! For desserts, I had the banana sundae and it was sooo good! It had so many elements to it & was great, I didn't want it to end. I think it was my favorite dish. My husband got the Tarte A L'orange and thought it was nice and thought the fruit that garnished it was nice too. All in all it was a great meal and I would return, however it was nice to have a deal with it being restaurant week. We didn't order wine on this occasion but be warned the wine menu is 84 pages long, so you might want to review it before you visit!!

I visited the 21 Club in the hopes of enjoying their restaurant week lunch menu with a guest. We arrived 5 minutes before our 1:30 PM reservation and were immediately addressed rudely by the restaurant's host. His eyes scanned us from head to toe and he quickly informed us that we couldn't be seated as our attire was against the restaurant's dress code (we were both wearing dress shoes, a jacket and dark jeans). This was our first time visiting the 21 Club and I told the host that we were never informed of a dress code. He haughtily threw a piece of paper at me which had a dress code typed in fine print, pulled from their website - it was obvious to me that he had done this many times before. I found it odd that he would so readily turn us away, especially considering the nature of restaurant week (is it not an opportunity for restaurants to attract new clientele?). After politely asking if we could perhaps be accommodated somewhere in the restaurant other than the dining room, he suggested we change our reservation to another day. I declined and enjoyed my lunch elsewhere. After going home I checked my credit card statement to find a charge of $50 on my card for a no show fee! Talk about adding insult to injury! Nowhere on the online booking site does it say that I would be charged for not showing up in attire deemed appropriate by the restaurant staff. Even if it did, this practice is immoral and discriminatory. At no point did I sign anything authorizing my card to be charged. I called the 21 Club and after speaking to the manager, he agreed and reversed the charge. While that may seem like a reasonable resolution to the issue I find the whole practice to be predatory - what if I hadn't checked my credit card statement? They would have gotten away with unjustly charging me $50 for no services rendered. They have a vested interest in turning away customers and not serving them food, since they charge their credit card anyway - there is something very wrong about this. I would never step foot in this restaurant again and I could not in good conscience recommend anyone else to.

Food is tasty, cocktails are good, decor is upscale kitsch think upscale Applebees ie alot of americana hanging all over the place.  Tuna Tartar was really good.  I really like it, but its way too pricey for what it is.
The 21 Club is old school cool. Had some cocktails on Monday and was very impressed with the service. Even got a chance a chat with the GM. Very Nice! I

Why have I eaten at so many steak houses when I eat steak so rarely? One big reason is I've been married for 11 years and when my father-in-law comes to visit for Christmas, he only wants to eat at steak houses. So, I have eaten at almost all of the NY institutions. As an aside, I worked as a hostess at Keen's when I moved to NYC and have some amazing memories, and the funny thing was I was a strict vegetarian at the time. I never ate their steak when I worked there.We did the Christmas prix fixe at 21 Club, and my father-in-law liked the atmosphere and the caroling, although they only sang to half the room and skipped us. I still remember my elk loin game medley was good, but everyone else was nonplussed by the experience. This was a few years ago, and it was a hefty price tag.I know their kitchen went through some rough patches there for a while. But that's what restaurant week is for. It gives classic institutions that have slipped a little a chance to redeem themselves or buff up their image. 21 Club is a NY legend, too. You have to go.
I really would never go back , food was not bad, however I didn't like the service nor the place at all. I didn't feel relaxed or enjoyed this restaurant at all.
Wintry weather calls for classic cocktails, warm soup, and steak tartar. Best place to get it in Midtown in 21 Club.

Look let's be honest the food here is not great , but I love going . The reason is not the food but the place itself . Somehow you feel good dining here . The prices for what you get are crazy , but you are getting the experience of dining in one of New Yorks most storied establishments
Such a unique place! The stuff on the ceiling makes for a fun game of I spy while waiting for your food! :) Our waiter was awesome and I definitely recommend the steak!

Froofy froofy New York exclusive restaraunt.  Ate here before attending a show.  The decor was cool: a bunch of figurines hang from the ceilings, each from a different famous person or another rich person who frequents this club.  I enjoyed my dinner: foie grase to start, duck for my entree and zabaoine for desert. It was all great.

It is a cool place to go to. Some people might enjoy it but I personally find it too stuffy. The tour of downstairs wine cellar was pretty cool otherwise the food is.not good. The service is attentive. I will not go back but I recommend it if you like to see the hidden cellar downstairs. Make sure the tour is available that time and day.

My husband and I went for drinks in the bar area and we had a lovely experience. I hadn't  been to "21" since I was in my 20's, fast forward 20 years and it is still the same iconic  place that I remember. My husband and I shared a couple of appetizers, mini burgers and walnut camembert. The burgers were outstanding, the cheese dish missed the mark. The standouts for us were the amazing service and our Maple Sour Martini's. We were told they were a seasonal cocktail but our server assured us we could order it at anytime and they would accommodate us. We felt the Maple Sour cocktails were in the top 5 of the best drinks we have ever had. The staff was charming and we had a great time.

If I could give zero rating I would.Update your 85 page wine list, please.  We must have selected 3 or 4 wines before being told they didn't have the bottle in stock.  Uneducated Sommelier is an under statement.We never met our Captain, the back waiter took our order the entire dinner.Let's skip to the entrees, I don't want to get into how their famous lump crab was fishy... They burned our steaks!  I know the difference between charred and burnt, the steaks were not edible. This place sucks sooooo sooooo soooo badly.  I live in NY and it's very apparent it's a tourist trap.  I hope this review prevents someone from wasting their hard earned money.

The place was crowded but we were met with laughter and humor and these were the other patrons! Loved the place immediately! Now this is what I imagined a New York bar! The waiter was so formal and cordial! Brought us our drinks so elegantly. He was so nice that he even went out of the way to get me a lovely book of matches! The "Manhattan" was a mind blower which the second one did just that! Blew my mind! Everyone seemed to be having a wonderful time! Maybe next time I can get one of those 21 baseball caps!

This place is extremely overrated !  Our uncle has been going there for 20 years and wanted to surprise us for the holiday season and gave us his table. We have heard nothing but "great reviews" about this restaurant and how hard it is to get into. We were privileged to go. We got there and had a drink at the bar. The bar in the front of te restaurant is amazing.  They way you would expect the whole restaurant to be. Unfortunately it's not.  The host walks you into the back room where the tables are topped with red and white checkered table cloths , seats are inches away and there are random things (Hess trucks, helmets etc) hanging from the ceiling. Never the less, we chose not to judge.  We ordered two Caesar salads. Honestly I could have ordered a side salad from Mc Donald's  and it would have been presented better.  We then order a chicken hash and I order lump crab meat.  My crab meat - which I was pretty excited for - looked like cat food and had tons of shells in it. The chicken hash just looked like beef goulash. All in all I was not impressed.  For a 150$ dinner - I would rather have gone to Delfriscos. That's a class act.  I enjoy going out to dinner and to new places. I enjoy they way the present their food and so forth, however I will never be going back here. Even if it were for free.  TERRIBLE - it was difficult to even give this place 2 stars.

Wonderful historic NYC "speakeasy" restaurant.  Fabulous tour of the wine cellar (a must - it's part of the ambiance).  Food was fantastico!  Best steak tartare hands down!  Atmosphere relaxing, romantic, fun.  Staff above and beyond.  And above all, I like that men must wear jackets.  It adds class to a world and country that seems to have lost touch with "old school" values.  Thank you for an incredible experience.

We had a party of 10 for 21 Club, and the experience was awesome. There was the Salvation Army there for Christmas caroling, which was an interesting experience. They went around to collect donations after. The menu was also pre-fixed.For the first starter, I got the Lobster Bisque (4.5/5). Then I got the duck (3/5) - great sized portions, but nothing out of the ordinary. Then I had the tiramisu (4/5). Overall, the food quality was high. They were very courteous, professional, and quick. The overall lunch took 2.5 hours, which was longer than expected, so keep that in mind.I would come back for business meetings for sure. Super swanky with a jacket required. There is a lot of old money in here!
21 club is such an experience. Anyone living in New York should try it at least once. Old school. Look sharp and enjoy your meal.

club 21 is great , their cesar salad is best in bar none and their service is top notch .. the ceiling is filled with all kinds of toys and trucks and sports helmets its one of a kind place I highly recommend you go here

We had an amazing closing dinner in the Wine Cellar.  We were ushered through the kitchen and down to the wine cellar and given a great story on why the wine cellar was created during the Prohibition Era.First Course - Caviar w/ lemon creme frauche and whole wheat blinisSecond Course - Foie Gras Au TorchonThird Course - Prawn RisottoFourth Course - Prime Aged Filet MignonDessert - Pear Tart TartinI loved everything except the dessert which I found too sweet.  There were many amazing wines served but my favorite was the dessert wine named Tokaji.The staff was amazing and knowledgeable.  They provided much needed descriptions of all the wines served.  We never felt interrupted as they guided our night along.

this is a vintage old school American restaurant. you can choose a table that famous people have sat in the past in the future. when you're in New York and you have the time and the money this is the go to place. the 21 club burger cost more than 21 dollars now. the wine list is extensive and very pricey. everything they do is done to perfection

Unique experience and great food.  21 Club has a lot of history, former speakeasy and when companies go public on stock exchange they hang their logo from the ceiling.  Great energy.  Roxanne in the ladies lounge is a hoot!

Brought a friend visiting from Texas here for lunch as he wanted to see more of the 'old New York' and this place is about as iconic as you can get.I hadn't been here in over ten years but it is still as great as it always was.Ordered the steak tartare which is the best preparation I can find locally. Almost identical to the style you get in France at the best bistros. He got the chicken hash which was huge and smothered with cheese and spinach. We both had a Caesar salad which was very good.Service was impeccable and the decor is always fun to admire. A must visit at least once in your life.

I love classic things and pairings.Cigar and sundays, tweed jacket with loafers and the 21 Club with nights that have classy as the theme.Went here and the night was perfect. Food and service reminded me about how restaurants should run. Food was so much better then I expected and the wine list was deep and interested.Easiest 5 star review I have written.
Unique place with different models on the roof. Food is authentic and of great taste. Price is a little bit high but overall a good restaurant.

21 club is a historic restaurant in NYC and was a must go for my first trip to the Big Apple. I am not sure if I just got my hopes up too high or if the food was just average. The service was BEYOND AMAZING. For an appetizer we had the jumbo shrimp which was great.  For our entree we ordered a filet and the rib-eye with a side of lobster potatoes. I could have had just the lobster potatoes and died happy. My filet was good (not great, just good) and my friend's rib-eye was medium to medium well, not medium rare. The drinks were stiff and good. Overall, it's a good must try historic restaurant, but I do not think I will be dining here on my next visit.

Saw 21 Club on a plethora of top 10 restaurant week (RW) lists so chose it as one of my RW picks to go to this summer. I had no idea of the historical significance of the restaurant regarding every U.S. president since FDR (except GWB) had eaten here and that numerous films were also shot here (i.e. Wall Street) prior to choosing it.On the outside, the restaurant looks classy, upscale and there's a nice touch with the little jockey figurines on the top of the entrance. My friends and I had dinner inside the Bar Room, which was really dark inside. The dim lighting could be looked at as giving off a romantic ambiance, but at the same time you had to have the vision ability of a bat to see the menu!The restaurant was once a speakeasy so it was understandable that the décor was unique too. There were all sorts of toys hanging on the low ceiling (trucks, airplanes, footballs, helmets, etc) and little statuettes and paintings on the walls. The table clothes were a red/white plaid color, which added to the "weirdness" of the room. The room definitely had an "old school"/1900s feel to it and is nothing like the modern, classy restaurants of today. A strict dress code is enforced here --- jackets are required for men (ties being optional now) and no jeans or sneakers allowed. The noise level throughout the night was moderate and not extremely loud. The Bar Room was not at capacity on the Tuesday night we visited, but it was almost full in our section of it.As for the RW menu, I was pleased to see that there were 4 of each course served. The RW menu was actually embedded within their regular menu with little jockey figures next to the RW items. Here's what I ordered:----- APPETIZER -----Beef Carpaccio - The thin slice of beef was not cooked all the way through, but was excellent and perfect for my palette! It was flavorful, almost like a giant, thin piece of pepperoni and was surrounded by some vinaigrette seasoned arugula and parmesan cheese.------ ENTRÉE -----Roasted Murray Chicken - Moist, juicy and tender. I loved the seasoning on the top of the chicken and it was roasted just right where it wasn't burnt, but I got that toasty flavor from the skin. The mashed potatoes were a good addition to the plate to fill up on.I also had a chance to try the Braised Baby Lamb Shank and I would have to say that would have been my #1 choice in retrospect. The Lamb was also extremely tender and the juices just spilled out with each bite. Also, the serving size was perfect and the Broccoli Rabe was really good! The only complaint I could have on it was the Couscous because I'm not a big fan of it.------ DESSERT -----Roasted Peach Tart - I also had a chance to try the Crème Brulee and Almond Chocolate Blondie Sundae and I highly recommend the Sundae out of all 3. The peach tart was caramelized on top but there was a little too much ginger flavor in it for me. The Crème Brulee was a classic brulee, so I didn't feel it was that special either. The Sundae was sweet, but there were so many delectable ingredients in there, including the blondies that we could dip in the sundae and little crunch balls.Overall, I liked the RW menu food, but not sure if I was fully in love. I found the décor to me very unique, although a bit odd. I didn't feel the Bar Room gave off the high-class environment feel, despite the fact that they have a dressy dress code. I did like that the RW menu had a 4-4-4 list and the wait staff was very professional. I would hate to give the restaurant a 3 because it was better than that, but it wasn't a 4 either, so I'll have to settle on 3.5 stars.

Meh. Cool history, cool venue, ok vibe (decent buzz inside bits little pretentious) but the food is pretty average heading toward rubbish if you do it on a cost adjusted basis. Way better options abound

This place was a wonderful experience for me. I had the calamari which had an incredible burnt taste to it, salmon for the main course and the blonde sundae for dessert. Everything was delicious and the portion size was just right. The salmon was so tender and the peaches and vegetables complemented it nicely. Although it was overall a good experience for me, the place was a bit too hot. It seemed like there was poor air circulation so having central air would have been nicer. Tables nearby also had issues with that. Additionally, I felt that the waiter rushed us a bit. Nevertheless, the food was good and the atmosphere was quite pleasant.

Service was great but the food was thoroughly mediocre and very overpriced for what you're getting. Its cool to be there for the history but that purpose would be equally served by having a drink and snack downstairs. I think our meal was around $250 (for 2) and it was average at best. Definitely could have a much, much better meal elsewhere for that kind of dough.

I have wanted to eat here ever since I was a little girl growing up in hillbillyville, reading about the glamorous lives of stars (of literature and film) in the 30's - 50's, and this restaurant was frequently mentioned. I thought I was making my reservation for restaurant week, but wasn't really paying attention to what I was doing, and wound up making it for a Saturday evening, NOT restaurant week. HA. I'm going to be feeling the sting for a while, but it was worth it.We dressed appropriately: suit and tie for my husband, dressy dress for me.  We came early so we could have drinks beforehand. When our cab pulled up (my shoes were NOT made for walking), a restaurant employee opened the cab door for us and helped me out.  We were greeted by the maître d and shown to the bar.The bar is the standout here.  They had my favorite gin AND they buy the tonic water in glass bottles. If you really like gin and tonic, you know tonic from a soda gun is just sub par. It's always, always flat, so the fact that they spring for the little Canada Dry bottles (the tiny glass ones, none of that cheap plastic bottle crap here) was a huge selling point.  The pours are extremely generous.Of note: the bartender asked if we were dining and when we said yes, he put the drinks on our dinner tab.   We had assumed we'd tab out at the bar and use a card.  We had no cash and there was no way we weren't tipping the bartender, so my husband ran across the street to an ATM.  Just remember that: bring some cash to tip the bartender if you're eating here.When the maître d approached to let us know our table was ready, we asked for a few extra minutes which was graciously granted. The table, incidentally, was one I had requested specifically, and I got it.  Yes, it's where Dorothy Parker sat! I'm a rube!  They asked me, "this is your favorite table?"  which made me sound like a regular and not a rube, which was appreciated.We got to the table and were greeted by I think a bus person or assistant. We were brought bread, water, etc.  The sommelier came by and when we told him our price range and what kind of wine we liked, he suggested a wine that seriously blew our socks off.  I saved the receipt so I could track the wine down locally.  It was every single thing we wanted, and about $40 less than our limit.We had the foie gras terrine, I had chicken, my husband had steak. The chicken was nice and juicy, the steak was delicious as well, cooked perfectly.  I had profiteroles, and my drunkard husband had a scotch for dessert.  They brought him some complimentary petit fours, which was nice. Everything was really good.The restaurant does close kind of early, 11 pm.  We were enjoying the desserts, running our mouths, and they had to tell us they were closing. Oops. Sorry, we were having too good a time to leave! Can we move in?We'll definitely be back.  If you're looking for a quiet, old school place to have drinks after work (and I do work in the area, so I do see this becoming a regular thing, yikes), this will do it. The music is Sinatra, etc., my favorite, and low enough you can enjoy the music while still hearing the people you're with. Great ambiance.If you're looking for a place to really splurge in a traditional way, this is it.  The ambiance, the service, it's all amazing. This is IT, the last of the great New York restaurants. The Stork is gone, El Morocco is gone, but 21 remains. And now I know why.

The wine cellar tour put this over the top for a 5 star review.   I came here with friends for the 2014 summer restaurant week and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  We were a little concerned that this club (which has served every president since Teddy Roosevelt) would be too pretentious and snobby for us to enjoy dining here.  But the service we received was wonderful from beginning to end.  (Perhaps it helped that we checked ahead on the 'business casual' women's dress code.)  The salmon and crab tartare appetizer was the highlight of my three course meal.  The vegetables served with the salmon main dish were flavorful and crisp.  And my friends very much enjoyed their lamb shank.  All of the dishes we tried were well prepared and we left full and happy.  Touring the wine cellar at the end of our meal was an unexpected highlight.  There is some fabulous history hidden behind a secret passageway that leads to the 21 Club's wine cellar.  Not to mention some fabulous bottles of wine.

Restaurant week summer 2014 reviewI came here for lunch with my coworker for restaurant week because it was in the neighborhood and boy was it a pleasant surprise! As soon as you walks in the whole place screams history and old fashion. If you've ever watched Charley Sheen and Michael Douglas in "Wall Street" the movie, it takes place here! Before we were seated, we were quickly stopped because my coworker did not have a jacket and was also wearing jeans! *Facepalm! We were seated in the lounge instead of the main dining room, which was equally cute and old timey. The main dining room had all kinds of old trinkets hanging from the ceiling, it's definitely one of a kind. The bathroom is also beautiful! The waiters are cute old people who were dressed up and super nice, loved it! The restaurant week menu was off of the regular menu, which is a huge plus as many nyc restaurant tends to put junk on the restaurant week menu. I had the beef capaccio, which was fresh and delicious! My coworker's grilled squid was also amazing!For main I had baby lamb shank, it was flavorful, tender and falling off the bone! The dessert was so so, but the appetizer and main more than made up for it. Overall the food was an amazing deal for restaurant week. Being able to experience the history of this place really made it a five star experience!
Awesome service and equally good food.. cocktail list is a must try.. don't miss the wine cellar tour..

Ask to see the "wine cellar", and tip the guy who gives you the tour $5-10. (Saw the other groups tip him also) No matter how you like the meal, the wine cellar and history lesson in this former speak easy is the best dessert. The bread was hit and very good, always a plus. Went for restaurant week. Tried the cold cucumber soup (cold soup not my thing- skip it) and calamari (average), and main course lamb which was very good and I'd recommend. Dessert I had the fruit but probably the sundae would have been a better choice . There is a dress code and men will be loaned an ill fitting sports coat to dine. The waitstaff was very nice, not sure why others have said orherwise. The dining room is fine but I'm not sure if all the model airplanes hanging from the ceiling adds or detracts from the character.

Interesting place with some cool decor.  My dinner experience was great.  Cucumber gazpacho with shrimp was flavorful and refreshing.  Lamb shank was absolutely divine..I wanted more of it.  The only downside was the dessert. My vanilla creme brulee was undercooked and wasn't anything special.  I would come back again.

The 21 Club was just fantastic.It feels very much like going back in time to a very classy era in NYC dining. Jackets required for men, and hosts who greet everyone at the door as if they are the restaurants best customer, rather than acting like they are doing you a favor as in so many restaurants here.The building is beautiful on the inside, reminiscent of dinner scenes from Madmen, you feel like you are at a fancy dinner in 1968 minus the cigarette smoke.Waiters in tuxes, table stewards in white dinner jackets, and a wine steward who still carries a tastevin.The menu is simple, and the dishes perfectly executed.We ordered off of the restaurant week 3 course menu for $38 each:Appetizers - Cucumber Gazpacho and grilled Calamari over ratatouille.Both excellent, the Gazpacho crisp and refreshing, the calamari perfectly grilled over a delicious Ratatouille.Entree - Orecchiette with roasted vegetables and Scottish SalmonThe pasta was very fresh with a kick of red pepper.Salmon perfectly executed, medium rare. The plating was particularly pleasing.Dessert - Peach tart and a fresh fruit plate.The fruit plate came with a white wine sorbet that was the highlight of the evening. The wine list here is extensive... like 300 pages extensive, and they have some very expensive wines, yet we were able to find a reasonably priced bottle or 2011 Mount Eden Chardonnay for $50.The restaurant week menu for $38 is an unbeatable deal for dinner at an NYC icon.

Come for after work drinks, lovely and low key atmosphere. They have great service and is a good place to take out of town guests, bushiness associates or for a special event like graduation or retirement celebrations.

This is where it all started. One of the first places to the table with the premium price burger. Not as hyped as it once was or as talked about as the other high priced burgers floating around the city, but the Club 21 burger still gets the job done.

I have driven by this place several times before stopping in and trying it out. Nothing to see or eat here. The Creamy Chicken Hash was also very dry and had no taste. Bad enough they serve food that's gone south, but then argue with the customer when they complain about it. I have never tasted something so bad! I was expecting much more especially after paying $40 for it. Food took for ever to come out. Highly disappointing. I will not be going back.Thank you and goodbye.

21 club is an NYC institution. Point.Blank. Period. Don't understand the negative reviews, as this establishment prides itself on getting to know you. They remember your face, and if you frequent enough..they remember your drink/ food choices.I work around the block, and often pop in with the bff for a catch-up session. I have also had a few company dinners in the Wine Cellar, the planning effort was extremely meticulous. It's just a feel good kind of place. Mature crowd, no juveniles, whether you are single or with your sig other, you will definitely feel be at ease in the relaxed environment!

Came here for lunch last year during Restaurant Week. They have dress code sports jacket for men and dress shoes for women. I loved the entrance, we were greeted and treated with respect and cordiality. The food was excellent, We will definitely come here even if it's outside of Restaurant Week..the food and experience is worth the money.

There are some places in the world you expect to be treated poorly because you feel like an outsider to the privileged 1%. And when you are not treated poorly, or conversely, treated like a king, you realize why institutions like 21 and Le Bernardin stay in business regardless of fad or trend. And the food at 21 is better than good if not a tad shy of excellent. And the prices are not breathtaking but the entrees run $30 plus.I've been here a dozen times in my life so I'm certainly not making anyone rich by my infrequent attendance but you'd never know it.I took my college roommate's son there last night who I prefer to think of as my nephew, and they made me feel like a Grand Duke ringing in a new heir.All hail 21. A storied establishment that just wants to be your friend.

Our original reservations were for Upstairs but when that was rented out they moved us with our permission to the Bar Room.  They make a good Blood and Sand at the bar.  We were a bit short on time before our show, so I was appreciative of our waitress that paced our meal appropriately to get us out on time.  I started with the chowder and my wife had the Oak and Endive Salad.  Both were flavorful and well presented.  I finished with the chicken hash which was like a fancy pot pie.  My wife had the crab cake which was not overly bready.  Overall a great atmosphere, great service, and great food.
One of the old standards in NYC. My grandparents dined here in the 40s. The entire experience is off the hook - just make sure you've paid the rent.

I don't understand the posts here about the required attire...you're dining one of the older and more respected places in NYC...act like it.I had probably the best martini I've had here, and the lobster and butternut squash bisque was a unique and surprisingly wonderful appetizer. The tuna tartare is also stellar.  The wife had the Dover sole which was complex, buttery and wonderful....I didn't have as good of an experience with my filet.  I ordered medium rare and got medium well. Chauncey, the waiter took it off the bill and when I thanked him he was surprised I didn't expect him to do so.Service from Chauncey was wonderful, but our first waiter asked if we were going to a show (we were and had limited time) but then ignored us for 15 minutes until Chauncey came by. This was a good place that seemed to have an off night. I'll be back for sure to give it a second try.

Dress up as jackets are required! I am glad I finally came to this NYC institution. Would I come again?? Only for the drinks. They were strong, yes a bit pricey, but good. Also the inside is just wonderfully decorated (not a fan of the dining room decor, but there's a story behind that), the bar/lounge is very nice though.

Heard mostly so-so things about this restaurant - with the biggest complaint being the staff and manager are pretentious p.o.s.  That sort of behavior typically doesn't bother me - I tend to look past it.  However this time I literally couldn't.  It's my dads 65th birthday.  I had high hopes for this day - nice walk through Central Park (fantastic weather), a nice dinner, surprise play tickets and then a nice walk to Jacques Torres for dessert.  Well it ended right after the walk through Central Park.  After repeatedly verifying the dress code - we were denied entry because a member of our party who was from out of town and didn't have slacks (but was wearing jacket, dress shirt, dress shoes, tie, etc) was deemed unworthy to enter.  Surprised, I explained the situation - my father's birthday, a reservation that's been booked for months, family in from out of town.  They didn't even blink.  In fact they just kept staring at us with a look of contempt like we were lowly pions and they were the Lannisters and pooped out gold.  Long story short - we were asked to leave and now hot dogs will have to be our meal of choice before the play. Thanks 21 Club.  Stay classy.

My mom and wanted to get a quick drink at the bar. We were turned away for wearing dark jeans. Then as we were walking away the doorman let two older white men wearing light blue jeans and white tennis shoes in right behind us. We asked the doorman why and he said they have a reservation. So I guess if you want to wear jeans to this bar make a reservation first, and/or be an older white guy.
the food isnt that good but the atmosphere is good for a date. older people tend to come more and its a place to drink wine/beer

We were running with the classic new york theme for a friend's roaring 20's (30th) birthday last weekend. With it's brilliant history as a prohibition era speakeasy, 21 club was a perfect for our night out.We committed numerous faux pas that evening:- The birthday girl wanted balloons. When you're the birthday girl, you get what you want. Especially at 30. I brought them along and got the feeling they were perhaps a bit obnoxious, even in the downstairs room clad with checkered tables and antique toys hanging from the ceiling. - I didn't know any of my my party mates (with the exception of the bday girl and her beau) but we were largely well behaved, even if we were a few decibels louder than the average table (oops). We ended up doing a round of shots. Yes, shots -- at 21 club. Our waiter politely obliged but I felt that really wasn't the time and place. - In line with the 20's themed party we had fake cigarettes. The birthday girl even had an Audrey Hepburn-esque cigarette holder that she was casually holding for photos. The look of polite horror on the waitstaff's face when we brought them out was a bit humorous. They were covertly trying to figure out what the heck we were doing and if they should put a stop to our shenanigans.Now, on to the food.Wanting to get a taste of vareity and leave with a full stomach, I opted for the 3 course prix-fix. I started with the crab cake which was pretty amazing and was richer than an oil rig owner. Seriously creamy and good. Only one came out on the plate but I could of devoured plenty more. The salmon main came out way undercooked but our waiter politely corrected this error. When it returned it was light, and full of baby new potatoes, not bad.The birthday girl brought her own cake and they charged some crazy amount to cut it and serve it.The Sorbet and fruit dessert was last dish down. Delicate and creamy and a light conclusion to my meal.My dirty martini came in at a grand total of $19. Ouch.I'm left confused. White glove service in a room of knick-nacks and checkered table cloths? While I liked it here, the value was negligible. Even for a NYC restaurant prices were a bit exaggerated.

We visited on March 5th and ordered from the Restaurant Week menu. All courses were delicious and my wife especially loved the bisque she had as a starter. We were intrigued by the toys and models that were hanging from the ceiling and we asked one of the gents looking after customers about them. The gentleman - Phil - obviously had intense pride about the place and told us about the history of this tradition, the restaurant and even about the table we were sat at. I found his love of the restaurant to be very touching and it added something special to our evening that was memorable.

What a disappointmentOur group of seven had a private room and the consensus was that we were not impressed.  One colleague said he had been to 21 Club about 100 times over the years and the place had really slipped.The food was average and service was arrogant and very inattentive (our captain disappeared for at least 20 minutes right after the meals were served).  At these prices, you deserve much better.

Such a charming restaurant! Loved the toy cars on the ceiling. It's truly a nice place for a special occasion. I had the lobster salad to start which was just okay. For entree, I had the Dover sole which was good but probably not worth the price. The pommes soufflés were amazing- fried hollow potato goodness. For dessert, I sampled the profiteroles and chocolate hazelnut cake which were both good. Cocktails are delish- I recommend the orient cocktail. The wine was also very good. Service is excellent. They also have a very reasonable prefix menu in the back of the menu. I'd recommend for everyone to try once.

Tip:- Men Bring Coat Jacket- Go Early For A Drink At The BarPros:- Service- Ambiance- House Bread- Creamy Chicken Hash- Classic Creme BruleeCons:- Cornmeal Crusted Crab Cake Okay- Slow Roasted Short Ribs Okay

Pretty good American style restaurant. We tried their famous short rib, really fresh meat! Also got the mixed grill of game - just too much for us to finish yet we both enjoyed the lamp chop. Cosy place as well:) just that the light was a bit too dim...

Wine, wine, and more wine!  Oh, the wine!  We came to 21 Club to check out the scene and check out this crazy wine list.  Firstly, the scene: Men, you must wear a jacket.  Don't be fooled by the toy trucks and football helmets hanging from the ceiling - this is no Applebee's in suburbia but rather a classy "New York institution" where rich business folks and celebs settle in for a $20+ cocktail (or two, or three) after work.  Make sure you dress the part - you won't be overdressed in your chic dress and heels.  I love that you'll see all kinds of folks here.... The romantic couple sharing an expensive bottle of wine, a group of girls out for a classy girls night, and the gobs and gobs of well-dressed super rich men at the bar, with gaggles of young pretty girls hanging over their elbows.  It's a sight to be seen for sure. As for me and my hubby, we came here for the WINE LIST, which is Ah-mazing!  Both of us had perused the wine list in advance.  You can download the "Wine Spectator Grand Award" winning wine list, all 84 pages of its glory), on their website or right here: 4c6c364fdf1082a37bcf-544…The wine list is divided by regions and the wine list has been so carefully put together to show you the maps of the regions and even the appellations and the vineyards themselves.  It's fun just to look at the wine list and all the maps. If you thumb through the wine list, you'll quickly notice that many of the bottles are sold for minimum $200-500, and upwards of several thousand dollars!  This is not wine for the novice!  Fortunately, there is a sommelier who is incredibly knowledgeable and helpful; bonus - he won't turn his nose up if you tell him your price range.  However, get ready to speak wine the right way - you can tell the sommelier "Yes, I'd like a red wine from the Burgundy region of France, vintage 2005-2010, fruity, preferably with some green apple tastes, but dry and well-balanced."  He will provide you options in your price range, and you won't be disappointed. Oh yeah... The food.  The food is great, too!  I highly recommend the crab cakes and the chicken hash.

Upon entrance into the restaurant, it feels as if you are entering someone's home. Warm and cozy, the friendly staff will assist you with checking your coat and finding you to your table in the dining room. The dining room is decorated with thousands of toys hanging from the ceiling in a fun ornate fashion. Yet, all men must respectfully wear a jacket while dining. Don't be fooled, the dishes are amazing and the drinks spectacular. The staff is happy to assist in anything you need or ask, and constantly kept an utmost level of professionalism and respect for your visit. All of this, with the amazing food, drinks, and service, will make 21 a place surely we return to.

Pros: Great Restaurant Week pre fixe meal, crab cake, prime rib short ribs that fell off the bone, and a decent creme brulee for $25!  Good portions and was a good deal overall.Cons: Staff was a little uptight, especially for a restaurant with toy cars, football helmets, toy planes and other metal objects hanging from the ceiling.  Also, would have skipped the two diet cokes if I knew it was $6.50. Definitely an NYC institution and glad I went, especially during restaurant week.
I went for dinner during restaurant week.  The food was good - i had the crab cake and short rib.  But the dessert was amazing - lemon curd ice cream and blueberry sorbet sundae.  So good!

I had lovely lunch party here. Celebrating my birthday with my friends. Nice decoration and atmosphere. The food was okay. Love the crab cake appetizer. I ordered the ribs, was good, but so tiny. The dessert i got chocolate larva thing, was ok, but my friends told them to do something about it, cause it was my birthday, they didn't do anything, so was disappointed. Other than that was great.

I came here last night for a friend's bday and during restaurant week. It's a nice experience with an old American feel. Cute decor with hanging cars, airplanes and helmets. They have a doorman greeting you at the entrance. Service was not bad except with all the staring. However, food came out extremely slow. Must've waited at least 20 mins between appetizers and entree.  What started as an early dinner took 3 hours to finish.  Most importantly, if you came here for food, you should turn back around. The food was definitely not even average.  I started with the tuna tartare, which was okay but not enough flavor. I had the salmon as my entree. I've had well cooked salmon before but this literally was hurting my teeth and jaw as I try to finish the dish. It definitely did not taste fresh. One last hope with the dessert...chocolate ganache cake. What a big disappointment!!! Tasted premade and was just sitting around.  The rasperberry smear at the bottom of the plate was extremely hard like they made it the day prior. As I get home, I'm feeling naseaus. Possibly the wind and freezing cold to blame?!?  No!!! Woke up in middle of night and all the food came coming out of my stomach and mouth.  Keep in mind that I don't even drink alcohol. It is all due to the awful food served.  Overall, I started out thinking I could get a taste of this expensive famous restaurant at a reasonable price and value, but ended up in total disgust.  I will never ever go near this place again!!Btw, I went to eat at Perry St the night before, and it was superb!

I'm kind of terrified by the review that you must be dressed up and the service of the waiter, but at least it's not true for me. I just wear shirts and pants, they still allow me in(though everyone is well dressed though). And I changed my reservation for THREE TIMES, but they still very kind! And the waitress and waiter is great especially the old gentle man at the front door. And I come for the restaurant week, except the entree is a bit little, everything is fine.

There are some 'old school' places that deserve kudos for being around for so long.and there are some that are just dinosaurs. kind of fun to look at them - but only in a museum environment.well - this place falls into the latter category.My friend took me there for the (tongue in cheek) adult experience after I turned 40.The decor of the place can best be described as a fusion of pre-historic disney and and gaudy overstuffed 30s.Tasteless decor with toy planes hanging from the ceiling. Lighting design is inconsistent and plain ugly.Why am I obsessing with the decor so much ?Well - you definitely would not come to this place for the food. Rumor has it that it used to be worse. But what you are getting for a horrendous price tag is simply an insult.I had braised short ribs. They were ok but everything was sort of bland, overcooked and smushy. Tuna tartar as an appetizer was completely bland.The sauces have no taste and no kick and could have come out of a can.To remind you: A burger at this place is 34 bucks. A normal steak is $68.If you like throngs of middle aged sourly waiters with depression era  haircuts you are definitely going to get a kick out of this place though....

Between "a fan" and "a-ok", I regretfully must pick an "a-ok" rating. I went there yesternight for restaurant week, and like most yelpers, I received a fluctuating service. The hosts, white jacket waiter, coat check lady, and doorman were superb, smiling and very polite. However, the rest of the servers were subpar. They weren't terrible but lack professionalism. I have been to numerous high end restaurants, and no matter how we are dressed the servers professionalism does not, and should not, change.Whether the servers we got were just having a bad day, or they were stereotyping us as "cheap tippers" or "low class" individuals, their reactions for a high end restaurant is unacceptable. I am fair, because if they were only a, let's say 2 star restaurant, I'll rate them as that. However, when you regularly, restaurant week aside, charge customers $34 for tuna tartare, I expect a certain service.First, they NEVER removed the bread or the dishes and instruments affiliated with eating the bread. This substantially decreased our table space causing unnecessary noise every time the server tried to put the food onto our table.Second, after I ordered the restaurant week dishes, I wanted to order more off the regular menu. The server in the black jacket just stretched out his hand and wanted to take my menu. I looked at him for a second to see if he'll withdraw his outstretched hand. ( I wanted to give him a chance to amend his reaction, he did not). I handed him the menu. Third, as a high end restaurant you NEVER say "you done?" You always politely ask, "are you done, sir/madam" before stretching out a hand to take the dish. There are other minor complaints, but I think I've made my point. These servers were snobby, and not classy. Classy is to present someone the professional and/or knowledgeable front the customer lacks. In a classy setting, the customer might feel inadequate because they are not accustomed to restaurant etiquette, and the server will gently nudge the customer in the right direction. It is NOT, the server BEING inadequate. (Please see my comments above).  If the server lacks that professional front, they are no longer classy. They are merely snobby, and I will not stand for that. I would have given this place two stars, if not for the other great servers and exceptional designs. The ceiling was just so amazing, filled with toys and football helmets. Coupled with classic wood furniture and small iron statutes, it was a sight to be seen. The food, is just okay. They certainly need a switch up the chefs. I have had better tuna tartare, fresher crab cakes, and ice cream that wasn't half melted when it was served. *Shakes my head* I was looking forward to this place too. Its not a surprise when I say the "class" and food of this place does not match the price of the menu.

The ambiance at 21 Club is not for everyone - you can call it snob or class. I prefer the latter. If you want the staff's respect, you better be dressed to impress. Suit and tie for gentlemen and dress for ladies is a must.You'd come to 21 Club not for its food (it's quite average and small portioned), but for a unique dining experience - mesmerizing decor, superb service. It's most known for the toy automobiles hanging off the ceiling (Coca-cola truck, firetrucks, airplanes, etc.). They speak for nostalgia. Reminiscing childhood - innocent times of our lives. This is the perfect date spot (although I came here with my gang). You simply will not run out of things to talk about with your date, and it's a dining experience she will not forget, and will recount to her friends.There are the framed vintage photos on walls, and auburn-colored wooden interior, dimly-lit dining rooms to give an intimate feel. You get the idea. Cheers to wonderful times.

Came here during restaurant week. The restaurant is old-fashion, spacious, with a lot of automobile toys hanging on the ceiling. The restaurant implements a strict dress code. Gentlemen must wear suit jacket. It was an interesting experience. However, I was not too impressed with the food. It was good, but not memorable. Overall, the restaurant was worth to check out (during the restaurant week) as It is one of the most famous restaurants in the city. Marilyn Monroe and Jackie O used to dined here. But if you are a foodie, this may not be your top choice.

I went for lunch at the Bar and the food was OK but the service was uneven.  The first greeter checked us in but then got our name wrong when he walked us to the Host.  Then the Host led us to an undesirable table right in front of the kitchen entrance.  But we did get to move to a booth which was better but then our waiter was grouchy.  After we placed our drink order, we got a different server who was more pleasant but then the Grouchy One came back.  We did enjoy our meal until two ladies next to us (dressed for foraging in a mall food court) hollered for their server across the room shouting: "Expresso, now!!".  That's not the restaurant's fault, I know but it was the perfect ending to an imperfect visit.That being said, I would give 21 a second chance but probably dine upstairs.

NO NO NO.  Some places are old and traditional but remain wedded to doing a great job, e.g., Peter Luger's in Brooklyn, Sammy's in Mendhem  NJ., Sam's Grill and Tadich Grill in San Francisco. And some places are laughing all the way to the bank, e.g., 21 Club.Started with Oysters.  Dry, glued to the shell.  Waiter/headwaiter not interested -- "just came from the vendor this morning." Well, the vendor must be someone's cousin. Then a steak.  A decent steak but you could do much better value-wise at, for example, Sparks.  And they have the story about the Mafia guy who got gunned down out front.New York is truly the "Big Apple" of the USA but there're plenty of worms in some of those apples.

If you are complaining about the food about the food, or that "dress code doesn't match the decorations," then you don't understand the appeal of this place. The atmosphere is unbeatable, and it's about as classic and "Old New York" as you get. Service is impeccable, and I wish there were more places like this. Spots like 21 are dying out in New York, being replaced by new, gaudy, shiny restaurants that will be out of business in 6 months. Long live "The Numbers" (as my Dad calls it).

My friend's 31st birthday is a reason for celebration, and 7 of us anxiously waited for Saturday night. I knew that the venue was pricey, and therefore did not eat much before, knowing that I would get an unbelievable meal. Unfortunately, I was disappointed. I decided to eat vegan that night, which left me with only one option: the vegetable tasting. That is all I ate. The portabella mushroom/ tofu tower had absolutely no taste. I cook my own mushrooms and they taste way better! The tasting came with quinoa stuffed peppers, which tasted strange and too nutty, and a winter squash ratatouille. The food was cold and a big disappointment. I drank a non alcoholic cocktail - which had grapefruit, lemon, maybe lime and some other juices. It was sweet and tasted good. Ok, so I get it: this is not a vegan restaurant. My friend, who sat next to me, was served a cold lobster bisque for an appetizer, and the game sampler for the main course. He confessed that the assortment of venison, elk, and other meats was not very tasty. For an average of $60-$80 a meal, WHERE IS THE FLAVOR???The service was acceptable, not remarkable, so I will give this place two stars.

Excellent service but subpar food for the cost. The whole place feels like an old school institution of New York which has its charm but may be a bit of an anachronism. I got the lobster salad and my friend got the burger. Neither were particularly compelling food items after trying them. The staff was very friendly and attentive though. I would go for the novelty and the atmosphere but not for the food.

We were in NYC for 2 plays in one day (2pm and 8pm), and needed to fit dinner plans in between. We decided on 21 Club because it was near the theatre and their prix fixe menu sounded appealing. Annnnd who doesn't want to have dinner in one of America's most famous Prohibition-era speakeasies?Overall: good customer service, really tasty bread basket, but the entrées weren't as memorable as we had hoped. The chicken breast was nice and juicy, but the filet of beef was dry and overcooked. The standout item of the evening was the fantastic (albeit overpriced at $17!) '21' Egg Nog signature cocktail. This cocktail even inspired me to try out my own egg nog concoctions upon my return home!We noticed that all of the patrons around us received a complimentary plate of macarons at the end of their meal, but sadly, we did not. Probably just an oversight on a busy evening. But guess what: I LOVE macarons lol. So this oversight stood out to me a lil more than it would to others. ;)

I have been here many times. Mainly for business group meetings where it is completely catered in the conference room. And everything is perfect. The filets, bread, deserts, etc. The coffee could be improved if I had to say one thing about it. But the ambience and everything else is wonderful.

Lunch in the bar---ginger carrot soup was amazing and the little toast crispsOMG. Really fun for people watching. The 21 burger was a little disappointing. It was rather tasteless even though it had lot on it-tomato,avocado, bacon,lettuce and the beef didn't have much taste.

Went for restaurant week several months ago. They sat us at a table with two seats side-by-side - yuck! There was something about the atmosphere that just wasn't jiving with me - I loved the toys hanging from the ceiling, but it doesn't match the dress code. The food was fabulous: the summer salad had an incredibly light yet flavorful dressing; the pork tenderloin was good, a little on the dry side, so they were kind enough to bring me more sauce; the creme brulee was great. The service was off. I would go back for restaurant week or on someone's expense account but definitely not if I'm paying full price.

I came here with my wife as we were in NYC for the weekend.  I had heard quite a bit about 21 Club throughout the years, so I was always curious to check it out. It did not disappoint, that's for sure.  We sat upstairs, and from the time we got there the service was great. Our waiter was extremely attentive and knowledgeable about the menu and wine list. I ended up starting with the octopus appetizer and it was delicious. Great seasoning on it and good way to start the meal. My wife had the caesar salad, and it also was very tasty. For our entrees, my wife had the scallops (delicious) and I had the Steak Tartare. Now, this isn't the appetizer type steak tartare that every restaurant has these days - this is the traditional french style steak tartare entree that very few restaurants these days serve, much less do a good job of preparing. I haven't had Steak Tartare this good in 13 years, quite possibly ever. Absolutely delicious. For dessert, my wife had the Nutella sorbet and I had the Creme Brulee. Creme Brulee was very good. I actually like the Nutella sorbet better though. All in all, I would highly recommend this for a romantic dinner in a NYC iconic restaurant. It's certainly a bit pricey, but worth it. Well done 21 Club.
Exactly what you have always been able to expect.  Well prepared food brought by well trained servers for well presented patrons.  About the most classic NY thing you can do, and you should.

Have always loved this restaurant and have been going for years.  Surprised at some of the mediocre reviews.  Food has always been consistent.  Yes, a bit pricey, but it is the 21 Club after all- perhaps the most iconic restaurant in NY history.  Regulars here have included everyone from Humphrey Bogart, Ernest Hemingway, John F. Kennedy and Jackie O. to Helen Gurly Brown and Mary Kate Olsen, and it has been in more movies than I can name.  Maybe some people don't get it but as far as I'm concerned, you can't beat the food and atmosphere.  It's always an experience.

Surprisingly delectable.  I took my family to 21 to show my kids the secret tunnels and the famous "meeting" room.  21 is, after all, an institution.  I expected them to be living off their name and just "calling it in".  I was surprised at how good it was.  My wife and Mother in-law both got the salmon which was just as good as anywhere else however I got the Paccheri Pasta:  rock shrimp, razor clams, sepia, bottargo, zucchini.  My two boys got the 21 burger which they both really enjoyed.  It was fantastic!!!!  The decor in the bar room was dated however this is what adds to it's aura.

I love this place. I've been three times - twice for dinner during restaurant week and once for lunch. The service is phenomenal and the decor is entertaining and unique - it's been consistent in this sense all three times. This place is not cheap, but you get what you pay for from a service standpoint and the food is very good. Furthermore, it isn't loud. You can actually hold a conversation. I will definitely be returning. Note: men must wear jackets.

This place has a ton of reviews so not sure mine will make much of a difference in anyone's consideration for going there... I have been to pretty much all of the city's old-school, upscale steak houses over the past 15 years... I've noticed a trend where these restaurants are relying much more on service and reputation and much less on the actual food they are serving.  21 Club is no exception.  The service is top-notch (though kind of weird, the waiter asked us if he could bring us a drink before giving us the drink menu... and then acted kind of put off when we asked for the menu...).  But the service is attentive.  Decor is interesting - especially in the tap room where the ceiling is adorned with old planes and toy trucks.  The more formal dining space is like any other old-school, nice restaurant.  Bread basked was nothing to write home about - not warm and not totally fresh but whatev...  Starter salads were very good.  For dinner I got the scallops which were delicious.  Mom got the sea trout ... not to be confused with fresh water trout.  i didn't realize this but sea trout is essentially salmon - in appearance as well as taste... not at all like fresh water trout.  her dish was served with an olive quinoa, which i thought i'd like much more than I did.  BF got the assorted game dish.  Personally, I don't love game-y dishes but I do enjoy venison.  He was kind of disappointed - the venison was extremely tough and chewy on the outside and extremely rare on the inside... All of the meat was VERY rare... cool to the touch, gel-like consistency.  I know many chefs prefer to cook their meats rare but it wasn't appealing.  With so many other places to get a fabulous steak, I don't think I'll be back.

Came in underdressed after theater on a Saturday.  After the eyeballing of our nice jeans, we were granted entrance. I guess we met the test albeit barely. Sat at the bar and had a great time. Spectacular martini. Just perfect. Beef slider and French Fries were as good as any I've had. All in all, I just had pub grub, but it was as good as pub grub gets.

Our cocktail wedding reception was absolutely perfect. Everyone thought it was a unique setting and we could not have received more compliments of the food! Our event manager James was very lovely to work with, he made sure we had everything we needed. We will definitely be coming back here for our anniversary!

I came here for a business luncheon. We stayed upstairs in a private room. Long story short. Everything was delicious! The arugula salad with the perfect amount of dressing. For entree, I got the chicken which was juicy and moist...shocker! I finished the entire entree. For dessert, I got the cheesecake which was soooo amazing because it wasn't overly sweet that I was able to finish it. And it was very fluffy not dense which I never had before. Everything was delicous from start to finish! I wish I can have more business lunches here!

Stay at the Bar, have a drink, see and leave. I've been wanting to go to 21 Club since I moved to NYC 4 years ago, my foody friends had warmed me that it was not what it used to be, but I had to find out on my own and went with a friend who was visiting from L.A. The place is an old world charm, very interesting decor, you can see the other diners, mostly tourist, all giggly when they first arrived. However, that charm does not translate to the food to say the least. The food was non-imaginative, I ordered the tomato gazpacho, and it was grainy, as if the tomatoes and whatever other vegetables had not been washed properly, followed by a non-seasoned breast of chicken, which my 5-year old nephew could had cooked better, it was dried, no sauce to be found.

There are antique toy figurines displayed on the exterior of the establishment. 21 club is located just behind the dark gates. At the descent we instantly time traveled to the1920s prohibition era. The atmosphere was dark, sophisticated, and mysterious. We looked up and saw various toys and sport goods hanging from the ceiling. These contrasting ornaments set club 21 apart from other expensive NYC restaurants.We heard many good things prior to the dinner and that may have inflated our expectations. The dinner began with sparkling water (Pelligrino $28 for 3) and we ordered a bottle of white wine (2013 Verdicchio - $28) to start. We were not expected to pay for the bubbly water. Sadly water was not covered. The white wine was on the restaurant week menu, it was alright for what we paid for. We had 2 attentive waiters for the night, a wine expert and a person who took care of our food. The wine expert explained to us the popular choice of wines and their distinct features. However, the wines he recommended were not meant for us rookies. Restaurant week menu for the Summer of 2013:Appetizer:Tomato and eggplant Gazpacho (Ratatouille)Summer salad Grilled ShrimpEntree:Grilled Pork TenderloinOrganic Chicken Breast w/ mashed potatoes Grilled Salmon with miso Dessert:Strawberry Rhubarb TartDevil's Chocolate PearlVanilla Bean Crème BrûléeAt the end of the meal, honestly, my group and I were quite disappointed at the food. The Ratatouille soup was cold, which I did not expect. It tasted like raw vegetables blended together. The best part of my appetizer was the one single piece of eggplant that was placed in the middle of the plate. The summer salad was extremely sour and uncreative. It was a combination of lettuce (a ton) and a few small cantaloupe pieces. The entrees were modest but unsatisfying. Both the Grilled Pork Tenderloin and Organic Chicken Breast were dry and unmemorable. The only redeeming quality was the buttery mashed potatoes, which tasted exquisite. The Grilled Salmon with miso was plain. My favorite part of the meal was the desserts. They were all delicious. The balance of crust to fillings of the Strawberry Rhubarb Tart was perfect. It was sweet and tangy yet not overpowering. Vanilla Bean Crème Brûlée came in sufficient serving. It was rich and creamy beneath the hard sugary coating. Last but not least, Devil's Chocolate Pearl was one intense dish, though it would be the perfect choice for the chocolate enthusiast. We got mini chocolate macarons and white chocolate truffles on the house, which was a pleasant surprise. Overall, 21 Club has an incredible list of wines and intricate desserts. The food was lacking but only due to the fact that the restaurant week menu was restrictive to a limited selection. Our bill came out to be $58 per person + tips and tax. If money was not an issue, this would be a wonderful romantic spot for couples.

I don't usually write reviews. It is the first time that I am compelled to write a review. My husband and I have been dining at many NYC restaurant now.
