So for our anniversary dinner, we decided to check out 21 due to its popularity.  We were greeted by fine lady and gentleman. That went well. First star goes for that. We were led to the bar room.  Then we waited forever for our menus to come. Finally our waiter came. He was SO serious. Never smiled, to the point that it made us feel uncomfortable.   Clientele is mainly white male. i feel like you have to be white and male to get a decent service here.  I had salmon, it was so plain no flavor whatsoever. My husband had roasted chicken, it was OK. The second  star goes for the treat they gave us, yummy macroons and white chocolate. There are many restaurants in NYC that has great food and service. Just go somewhere else where they appreciate your presence. We would never go back.

What a great luncheon we had at this historic New York restaurant.  So much history and yet all those who greet and serve you are spectacular examples of what makes this restaurant so special.  My friend had dined there a few weeks before and the waiter Kyle  remembered her family and came over to say hello.  The food was delicious and everything was served in a professional manner.  You never had to ask for a second or third cup of coffee it was just served without fanfare.  I'm a native New Yorker and I've been to many of New York's finest restaurant but missed visiting the Club.  It was the first for both me and my husband but I know we'll be coming back.  We loved the Bar Room and so did our little nephew who was in awe of the ceiling covered with toy trucks, planes and other memorabilia.  It was a wonderful afternoon.

The food and drinks were good. I came with a group, and my bill was covered, but the place was so expensive that I felt very uncomfortable. Our bill for eight people came out to $1,500. Jacket 100 percent mandatory.

Came here for restaurant week with a couple of friends, and ordered straight from that menu. The interiors are really cool when you first enter, with that feeling of having stepped into a chapter meeting of a secret society. Everyone is dressed to the nines, with jackets and ties everywhere. I'm personally not a huge fan of the jacket requirement, but I do love the formal attire. The clientele is either well-off, young people or some more established older folks. Definitely a few lookers here and there.Having said that, the actual dining area inside was a bit unexpected. First of all, the ceilings were extremely low, making this place feel super small. It didn't help that the area wasn't too large in the first place, making it feel extra cramped. Second, there were a bunch of random helmets and objects hanging from the ceiling, which erased some of that classiness you first felt. The food itself was alright, but I honestly expected more for something of this caliber. My grilled shrimp appetizer was probably my favorite out of the 3-course meal, with the miso-glazed salmon and vanilla bean crème brûlée not too far behind. Don't get me wrong, everything tasted fine, but nothing really blew me away.What bumps this place up to four-stars, however, are their complementary macaroons and white chocolate pieces and their parking deal. They have a parking agreement with the nearby Central Parking Garage (31 west, 52nd st), where you can park for 6 hours at the mere price of $10. This is an absolute steal when it comes to parking, and alone makes up for the price of the food.Just be wary though, because only the 31 west, 52nd st location has a deal with the restaurant. Any of the other Central Park Systems don't count towards the discount (I learned this the expensive way).Overall, I've had better food, but the location and parking is unbeatable.
I ate at the 21 Club a year ago and my girlfriend still compares her food to the chicken we had here.  Awesome food and a cool place.  Definitely check it out.

I had been once before with a group and had a great time. So I brought this group of five, (my husband and I, plus three friends from Finland) , making the guys wear sportcoats (they're required), and then I felt a little nervous when I looked at the menu and saw they offered a burger for $32! Yikes! I gulped and wondered what the rest of the group was thinking of the menu. I mean, the place is a NYC icon, but still . . . Then I turned the page and saw the prix fixe menu for dinner which included three courses and cost $35! Deal!!! Now, it was "Restaurant Week", and the prix fixe was part of that promotion, so I don't know what the cost would've been during a regular week.Anyway, we all got the $35 deal, and everything that everybody had was fabulous! The restaurant is very cool with all kinds of antique toys and memorabilia hanging from the ceiling. We could overhear the waiter at the next table chatting it up with his patrons about the history of this and that piece on the ceiling; we found ourselves wishing he was our waiter, as our waiter was pretty lackluster. Oh well, you can't have everything! And our waiter wasn't "bad", he just didn't have any spunk or any anything to distinguish him. However, the waiter didn't dampen our evening. It was a wonderful night in a landmark restaurant, and we were so glad we'd gone!

Risotto was good but I was very hungry, steak 2 star- over cooked medium rare steak with a odd tasting potato dish. Salmon with the potato fingerlings was good and dessert was okay. It had a great, vintage - classic motif though. I am glad that I tried it to see the decor but I would never go back.

The 21 Club is still one of New York Cities Best. Reservation are needed , and you can make them by phone or computer. The wait staff is the very best, and the meals are the best. They have daily specials for lunch and dinner. Its a well run operation and you will enjoy a meal here at the 21 Club.
Over-rated establishment restaurant. If you have a special party you can try the downstairs rooms.

Great food and service.  The 21 Burger was worth every penny, loaded with haricot verts, and other veggies.  My son had the game plate which he consumed voraciously.   The atmosphere is what you would expect...classic, old school.  A great experience.

What began as a speakeasy in 1922 has survived as a landmark. Midtown eatery offers an imaginative range of menu selections, complimented by a legendary wine cellar. Rub elbows with some of NY's social elite before a broadway show perhaps. Sit under a plaque that reads Bogie's Corner. The peppered tuna with a shrimp and avocado roll or crispy black sea bass with truffled potatoes and champagne sauce are all part of the American fare here retaining the tradition of excellence. Pricey and often not comparable to other restaurants in the neighborhood.  Not open all the time.

How can you rate 21 anything less than a 5? It's an American institution, one which each of us should experience at least once regardless of where we live, how much money we make, or what we normally eat.In his continuing quest to educate me in the area of upscale culinary delights, my father brought me here when I was 15. Although I was still too young to fully understand and appreciate 21's greatness and class overload, I still knew even then that I was experiencing something special. Subsequent visits have only served to reinforce this original, less sophisticated opinion.21 consists of two dining areas: the bar room, which is the main space that you've seen in dozens of movies and tv shows, and the upstairs room, which offers a much more romantic atmosphere (and charges more as a result). Both are fantastic, and I fully recommend that you all try them as soon as possible.Some nights, 21 offers a pre-theater prix fixe menu (I believe it's Tuesday through Friday- not positive though), but outside of that you'll be ordering à la carte. The pork belly, tuna tartare, and mesclun salad are all fantastic- or, if you'd like to really splurge, you can't go wrong with any of the three caviars 21 always offers (they change from week to week). And although a caesar salad probably doesn't seem all that flashy and interesting to you, the "21 caesar" is really great.As for the main course, the salmon and 21 burger are both delicious (don't knock the burger until you've tried it), and all the steaks are amazing too (as they should be for $52+). The asparagus and onion rings are crazy good- I wish I could have an order shipped to me right now. And although I can't speak to what's currently on the list, 21's cheese service is always a favorite. The last time I was there I had some roquefort that was to die for.Desserts are classic American (specifically NYC) fare done to perfection: cheesecake, crème brûlée, apple crumb pie, etc., but also look for more unique options that are added day to day. No matter which way you go, you'll be happy with your choice.The wine list is far too long to explain with any shred of adequacy here, so I'll leave it at this: not only are some of the best bottles in the city found at 21, but the best sommeliers to go along with them. Sit back, order 2 or 3 bottles for the table, and enjoy yourselves.21 is a restaurant that will never go out of style, as all truly classic institutions in life never do. It's a wonderful way to spend an evening in NYC, and an even better way to try American cuisine prepared with an exceptional level of flare, inventiveness, and love. Not to be missed.

Still can not figure out how this restaurant could charge my card $50 without my approval. Their reasons to my bank was because of "no show". However, I made the reservations through open table and there were nothing about the no show fee when I made the reservations. How could they charge the card without my approval. They even refused to work with open table to solve the issue.  I called the restaurant and the person at the phone changed her attitude right after she knows I am calling every time and transferred me to their "accounting" line that apparently never get picked up and returned calls. "What a wonderful service! "The service quality and their attitude of helping customers are not the same as they quoted themselves on their website "Experience authentic New York at its fines". There are so many better and fancier restaurants than 21 club. If you have options, please have 21 club on the bottom of your list or just remove it. There are just too many great things need to experience in NYC before wasting time and money here.

Okay so I've been waiting for the perfect place to have my 100th review and this is definitely it!Now to start with the restaurant... we all know the song and dance about the history of the 21 club... oh you don't? I shall enlighten you a bit then! Back in the 1930s, the 21 club was a very popular speakeasy spot for horse breeders to talk and brag and share a brandy. Being quite the spot, the breeders began giving the club these little colorful jockeys to represent their private farms. These jockeys were often replaced by winners and now they each represent some of the most successful stables and race horses. Interesting eh? Anyhow, so this speakeasy turned restaurant is as packed with history and memorabilia as it is packed with rich folk. Does the place radiate money? Yes... but are they snobby? I didn't think so. I actually found everyone to be very friendly! BUT keep in mind their "no jeans" policy... they take it seriously and you will feel seriously under dressed if you decide to ignore it. Girls are in cocktail dresses and guys are in suits. Doesn't matter the time or day of the week... so keep your attire in mind. Oh and the food... my GOSH the food... everything was FANTASTIC. A great selection of wine...the scallops were fresh and sweet, the steak was melt-in-your-mouth tender and their wine selection was fantastic! They chocolate souffle was outstanding and if you have a chance... try the peanut butter and jelly ice cream... YUP! I SAID IT! AT THE 21 CLUB! :)The atmosphere is dimly lit, richly decorated and incredibly romantic... my boyfriend... er, fiance took me here for our anniversary, and oh, he also proposed. :)
The tables are very close.   For the price the ambience is terrible.  So crowded.  Looks like a picnic area.    The food was good but not worth the price.  This is just another tourist trap

I'm beginning to think all these old-guard expensive restaurants that become 'institutions' in the city (21, Le Cirque, Tavern on the Green) all  use the same menu. I recently ate at 21 and was served incredibly bland food from start to finish: tasteless underseasoned salmon, steamed asparagus with nothing - not so much as salt, too much vinegar on the greens, and a beet couscous concoction that reminded me of airplane food - it was basically like steamed cardboard. Yes the service was good but unless you just want to experience this place once and check if off your list, go elsewhere. Why pay so much for bland boring food?

The quintessentially snotty Old New York place to eat.We went here prior to going to the Opera.  We sat in the back amid all the crazy crap on the walls, like Uncle Moe's Family Feedbag, but classier.  If you are going to eat steak tartar, especially for the first time, then this is THE place to have it.  Looks like hell, but simply delicious, served with onions and capers.  The beefsteak tomatoes were great: bacon and blue cheese - c'mon! I thought the service was fine - formal, yes; condescending, no.  Eyeing some of the diners were a hoot: blue hairs out with the younger generation, wondering if the grandkids are just dying for the old bags to kick off and get their grubby mitts on their cash.  Go and enjoy, but bring cash - or your AmEx Platinum.

I'm a little surprised about the bad reviews...we really liked this place.  Yes, it's expensive.  Whatever.  We had great service from the start. We were a little early so we opted to have a drink at the bar.  We chatted with the bartender and he told us all kinds of stories about the bar.  The waiters got into it too and it seemed like a fun group. Once we were seated the service was fantastic.  The tuna tartar app was quite good. The steaks were fantastic - it's sad to say, but it's been a while since I've had a good steak. The room filled up and it was a great atmosphere.  We were also able to get a tour of the wine cellar downstairs.  We'll be back the next time we're in NYC!

4/5 stars for me. It is not often that I find myself at fancy restaurants. Once in a blue moon for a special occasions I guess. I found myself making reservations here through work and was very excited. Jackets were required to sit in the dining room. For those that are going here or even stopping by for a drink at the bar, do yourself a favor and ask questions about the place or read up on it. There is so much history to the 21 Club. I did some reading beforehand and when we arrived we sat at the bar for a drink before our reservation for dinner. I asked the manager if it would be possible to see the wine cellar. He arranged for us to take a walk down, through the kitchen, to the cellar. A gentleman explained to us the history of the wine cellar through the prohibition era. It was well worth it. I could write more about it but I hate painstakingly long reviews. Some of the specials were really appealing but I went with a classic dish, the Chicken Hash. I was glad I did. Everyone at the table had one of their classics and everyone was pleased. I will mention that the service throughout the entire night was impeccable. The place has that old New York feel to it, when going to dinner was an event and not just a modern, casual night out. People dressed up, impeccable service, great food, doorman shakes your hand on the way out and asks if he can help you get a cab. I was very impressed with this place and will be back. Until next time.

Old Speakeasy from the 1920's.  Expensive and place to be seen.  Wine is the thing. Ask to see the wine cellar and secret door which is actually a pathway to another buildind used during prohibition.  It weights two tons and it is opened with a long steel rod placed in one of the many holes in the door.  Once triggered it is feather lite.  Very cool.  Food is very good as well.  It is the whole experience and the nostagila that makes it a worth while experience...........
Expensive, pretentious, mediocre meals! Typical old classic American type of place,  not really my cup of tea if I'm gonna be paying that much for food. Will not return.

The food here was surprisingly disappointing given the history and reputation of the 21 Club.  I actually like the fact that you have to wear a jacket to eat here, but inside it's a bit dreary and old.  I bet some would say there's a certain charm to the interior, but I'd say it just reminds me of my grandma's house.  The food itself is really nothing special at all, especially given the price point.  Disappointing experience.

Took my cousin and his wife to dinner there to congratulate them on their wedding. Good food, great wine, place is too over the top, uncomfortable atmosphere. Not my kind of dining. When we returned the second time to give it another shot, we were turned away because my husband had his polo khaki shorts on, no long pants. It was 95° outside, and we could have been offered a seat at the bar.We will not return again.

The Cocktails & Bar Staff ABSOLUTLEY FABULOUS - However, the full dinner menu served in the dining room is PAINFULLY MEDIOCRE and heavily overpriced for a non impressive meal. I suggest having cocktails here - just make your dinner reservations at one of the great restaurants right near by 21 Club.
Need a jacket to enter the dining room.So we sat at the bar instead. Bartenders were cool but not annoying. Food was great.

What a disappointing experience.   It started off with some bad service.   We got to our reservation 1 hour early because our show finished early.   We asked if we could be seated earlier by chance.   We understood if they couldn't because we showed up earlier.   But the maitre d' said just a few minutes.   We sat at the bar and grabbed a drink, patiently waiting for them to seat us.   We asked 2-3 times how much longer..."a few more minutes" they said...1 hour later, we got seated- at our original reservation time!   That's fine, but just tell us that you can't seat us any earlier since we were the ones that showed up early.  Bah.  Anyways, we were really looking forward to our meal.  This place has been around for awhile and had a bit of a reputation, so we expected a great meal.   We went for the restaurant week menu.  My husband had the salmon tartar and I had the salad.   The tartar was average but my husband has had better.  My goat cheese with greens was ok...there was too much salt in the dressing and it was pretty boring tasting.  We were hoping for more in the entree.  My husband got the shrimp, cod, and scallops...once again average.  We have had better.   I got the chicken with mashed potatoes.  Pretty average as well and nothing special about it.   We were getting pretty discouraged about the food by the time desert rolled around.   We secretly hoped that this is where this place shined...nope, it wasn't.  My husband got a coffee brownie desert and I got the creme brulee.  I was pretty embarrassed that they served the coffee brownie the way they did.  It was in a sundae cup with a bunch of chocolate syrup poured in the bottom, a chuck of brownie thrown in, some store-bought coffee ice cream plopped on top.   Topped off with canned whipped cream.  It was gross.   My creme brulee was ok.  It was less than average and served cold.  I couldn't have more than a few bites. To finish off our negative experience, it took forever for the waiter to get our bill.  He was just standing there, and kept looking at our table but not getting the clue that we were done.  Shoddy service.    We were pretty relieved we experienced this place during restaurant week and didn't have to pay normal prices (~$30-40 per dish) for worse than average food.  We've lived in NYC for about 5 years now and this meal is close to the bottom of our restaurant experiences.  So disappointing. I'm not sure if it was because it was restaurant week that they felt that they should serve worse than average food or if the food is always that bad.  All we know is that we won't be returning here anytime soon.

Since I've been dining here (even renting out rooms on occasion) for more than 40 years, obviously I'm a fan.  Pretty much everything you're ever likely to hear - good or bad - about the place is, or at some point was, probably true.  Yet some things remain the same.  The food can be excellent.  The ceiling in the main DR downstairs is a trip.  The private rooms and function-capabilities are outstanding.  The Wine Cellar is spectacular.  Order the Chicken Hash 21.  It's the best.

I almost walked out.  Almost.  I'm glad I didn't, but it still leaves a bad taste in my mouth.  I walked in and approached the desk-type-thing at the entrance, the first thing I laid eyes on.  The gentleman manning the desk says hello, starts greeting me...and then Someone Else walks in behind me.  Someone Else this gentleman obviously knows as a patron.  So instead of finishing up with me, he turns to Someone Else, greets him effusively and seats him at his bar table.  He comes back to me and I say, "Oh, so you're ready for me now?"  He says, "I'm always ready for you" and I roll my eyes.Anyways, I'm hungry, I have a long night of work ahead of me and god damn if I'm not going to have my RW meal.  Another thing.  If you have multiple places where you check in your guests, don't be all confused when your guests don't actually know this.  These 2 desk type places are about 12 feet apart.  Really, dudes, I don't care if I'm in the wrong "spot"--but it's your job to get me there.RW meal and menu was perfunctory.  Nothing special.  Nothing that made me say, I want the fancy version of this (perfect example?  grapefruit coupe at Boulud Sud oh my gooooood).  The bar was funk and it's across the street from work, so I'll be back for overpriced cocktails and bar snack and men in suits.

My boyfriend and I were very excited to try the 21 Club.  Unfortunately, the food was barely decent, the service awful, and the atmosphere left much to be desired.  We were seated around 8pm, after waiting about 15 minutes.  Our waiter initially seemed attentive, but something tells me that when we ordered off the Restaurant Week menu, his interest disappeared.  45 minutes later, we still had not received our appetizers, nor had we seen the waiter again.  A busboy dropped off some stale bread and that was it.  I literally had to flag the waiter down from across the room to ask about our food.  He seemed confused when I noted that we were waiting 45 minutes for a salad.  He reappeared about 10 minutes later with the appetizers.  They were fine - not as good as expected given what they normally charge for those plates.  About 10 minutes later our entrees arrived.  My boyfriend received a clearly undercooked scallop and my pork tenderloin was cold.  As if it had been sitting out for 45 minutes....We sent both dishes back.  My boyfriend received a new plate of food that was properly cooked.  I unfortunately, received the same plate and it was still cold!  My guess is they didn't want to put it in the microwave for too long because it would turn the already tough pork into rubber.  I sent my plate back again.  Finally, on the third attempt, they managed to bring me a hot meal.  Given the prices at this place, the service and food should be incredible.  I have had better meals at IHOP - and better service.  We used Restaurant Week as an opportunity to try this place, to see if we would want to return.  Absolutely not.  There are too many good restaurants in NYC to throw money away on an over-hyped place like this.
Very nice.  Exactly what I expected.  Too expensive.  In the back of my mind I was still hoping to see Woody Allen come out and play his clarinet. A special place to go for the history!

Came here on a Thursday night to have a drink with an old colleague. I instantly felt out of place as this felt like a "white male only club". But minutes later, the feeling passed. I was just at a bar (a pricey, fancy one at that) having a drink with a friend, just like every other patron. And there were a handful of women there besides me and my collegue. People mentioned loudness but I did not find this to be the case the night I went. 21 was quiet enough for us to have a conversation and there was space at the bar. I hate having to jostle people aside just to get to the bar and then having to stare down the bartender just to order my drink. The bartender at 21 was attentive and friendly and my martini was excellent. Thank goodness I was not paying the bill. I think our two drinks came up to $40/50. I would not come here again because I would gag if presented with $25 check for 1 drink.
Old school restaurant with a good atmosphere.  The food is nothing special and is overrated.

Fantastic food, seamless and smooth service.  this is dining and not just eating.  everyone is treated as if they are important with polite service.  My steak was tender and perfectly cooked.  The salmon was moist and delicious.  Even the potatoes were yummy.  well worth the money.  Treat yourself.  A gem.

I was impressed with my meal. Went with co-workers and everyone left happy. I started with the Ahi Tuna Tartare, which was good. Not a large portion, but I would get it again. My co-workers had the Foie Gras, which was just added to the menu a couple days ago. They really liked it. For dinner I had the bass, which was a nice size portion served with tiny brussel sprout. The only thing I would change with my meal would be the cocktails. I had the Mountain Lodge and was unimpressed. Slightly better was the Winter Wonderland my co-worker had, but I still wouldn't get one. I would just have a beer next time to go with my meal.

This was my second time at 21 Club with my coworkers, although the last time I've gone was a long while ago, so it felt like my first time.This time I ate in the "downstairs" lunch area.  The place is very crowded and very noisy.  The waiters keep hitting me in the back of the head as they passed - without even an excuse me which annoyed me to no end, but on to the food.I started with the crabcake appetizer as the waiter said it was what he recommended.  It was average - I've had better but I've also had worse, nothing to write home about.  For my main course I had the filet mignon and asked for it to be cooked medium.   It was a nice size steak and it was accompanied by green beans and a potato cake.  The steak, though was cooked medium well so it was a little dry and overcooked for me.  I was a little disappointed.  For dessert I had the creme brulee, again, it was average nothing really to write about there.Overall  I was a little disappointed in the food at the 21 Club not so sure if I would choose to go back again.

Not a fantastic experience at 21 Club.  Service and food were both medicore at best.  I came with a group of 6 on a Wednesday night.  The dining room is packed.  Although I absolutely loved the exterior of the building, the interior was a bit old fashioned.Service:  The sommelier is rude.  Yes, I am sorry we were late but since we already sat down, there is no need to give us an attitude.  Also, we have a decent size party and the restaurant is kind of loud.  We can't always hear each other.  One of us told the sommelier to chill our white wine.  5 minutes later, the other one asked to bring out the bottle.  I understand he might be frustrated but to be complaining about us right in front of us to another waitress?! That is just plain rude and unprofessional.Chill Seafood Platter:  It's okay.  Have had much better platter elsewhere although the grilled octupus does have a very interesting flavor.Appetizer:  I ordered the beet salad.  There are not many beets in there.  I had to look for them!  The flavor is pretty standard, nothing unusual.Entree:  I got one of their classic dishes, the chicken hash.  Uhhh.  It's not bad but it tastes like something served at a chain restaurant.  The chicken was cut into cubes layered with frozen spinach and wild rice baked in the oven with lots of cheese on top.  I don't see any creativity and honestly the dish seems very "homey". Nothing wrong for being homey but seriously wrong when it costs $37!  3 other people at my table ordered the steak.  All of theirs were overcooked.Needless to say, we were all disappointed and much preferred our dinner at Bobo, which was cheaper too!
One of the best meal i had so far, went w a couple of friends n sat at the wine cellar room was a great experience, fantastic wine n service.

My husband came with me on a business trip to NYC last week and we decided to try 21 since it had been many years since we both lived in NYC and it held some good memories for us.  We were unpleasantly surprised by how touristy the place has become. (The couple sitting next to us were taking flash photos of the ceiling memorabilia all through the meal.)  We had to ask twice to be moved to a table at which we could actually carry on a conversation, as the first two tables at which we were seated were so tightly cramed into each other that one practically was sitting in the laps of the adjacent strangers!  Next, we tried to order wine by the glass, but were told by the sommelier that the ones we chose were not very good, and suggested instead a bottle of French white that was $135, and we fell for it.  The wine was a bit turned and very thin ... just not good at all.  In fairness, they did deduct the cost from our bill, so we were saved from that problem, although the sommelier gave us dirty looks throughout the rest of the meal!  The food, when it was finally served, was quite good, so no problem there.  On the other hand, it was nothing to write home about.  Maybe we looked like we just fell off the turnip truck, as they say, but we really felt this was an expensive and not very fun experience.  We would never go back.

The bartender had that whole old-school service routine (think Peter Luger) where he was bordering rudeness. If you're into that, then he's your man, if not, wait till the table to get a drink. I guess going to a "classic" restaurant like 21 Club, I should have expected that, but I'm not a fan.The sommelier was pretentious and condescending. Again, not a fan.The waiter was really friendly and accomodating. A definite relief from the rudeness of the prior two servers.The bathroom attendant is the friendliest guy in the place (weird, but worth a visit to have a quick chat, bring a dollar or two for tip).I've been focusing on the service here so far since the food was so lackluster. And I've been curt because that's what the restaurant is...curt.The littlenecks on the halfshell were ok until I had a bad one. The crabcakes were good, but came on a tiny breadplate. I think this was done on purpose to be able to fit on the table for us to share, but that also meant leaving out the sides/presentation of the dish...not cool...The halibut for main course was mediocre.Overall...I think 21 Club wins a lot of diners over with its old-school charm, but by "charm", I mean subpar service and disappointing food in a stuffy setting.

My most recent discovery is savored.com  Where have I been?   I'm usually an early adopter of restaurant discoveries / news.  Anyway, Savored works like OpenTable except you can make a reservation at off-peak times and get up to 40% off of your bill.  We got 30% off of our bill ($171) for a Monday dinner reservation at 7:30pm. My friend chose the 21 Club as the starting point of his BNO*.  This is definitely a place where the masters of the universe congregate.  Jackets are required for gentlemen and the place feels like stuffy old money (the sommelier tastes the wine before you to confirm if it is acceptable) .  We dined in the bar room with football helmets, trucks, and model airplanes hanging from the ceiling (it reminded me of old school Keen's with the pipes on the ceiling).  We went with the following:- Royal Sterling Caviar: they only had 1oz left and it was $125/oz ("opulence, I has it").  This was the birthday boy's call and there's no objecting on BNO.  Splitting 1oz between 3 guys was like Jesus feeding 5,000 people with 5 fish/5 loaves of bread.  We all silently studied each other's scoops of caviar because spilling one grain would be the ultimate party foul.  It was good, but it wasn't $125/oz good.  It's pretty hard to evaluate while dividing an ounce three ways.- Oysters (Blue Points, Malpeque, Saint Simon, Watch Hill, Kusshi, Cherrystones, & Littlenecks): the oysters were OK and seemed a little on the small side (I'm spoiled by Aquagrill).- Halibut with Lobster Mash Potatoes Special: the fish was cooked well and was very good, but was on the small side and the lobster was almost non-existent in the mash potatoes.  The sides that we got were individually sized, but at least the fries were good.____________* BNO = Boys Night Out (we have a tradition where the birthday boy picks where he wants to eat, pray, love and the rest of us have to subsidize his requests).

Everything was going swimmingly until the sommelier came to our table. Possibly the rudest wait staff I have encountered in a very long time. I expected to be blown away by the selections and was underwhelmed by both food and wine.   Too many other great choices in the area. Go to Gilt instead!!!!!!!!

From the outside the 21 Club just looks like the place to go. The line of painted cast iron lawn jockey statues which adorn the balcony above the entrance create a unique image that no other restaurant in midtown has to compare. After many months of pining after the 21 Club I finally took advantage of an opportunity to experience the 21 Club during restaurant week....BIG MISTAKEI went here with some coworkers and upon entry it was Stuffy, dimly lit and a little too crowded for my taste.Yes, I ordered from the Restaurant Week menu and sad to say it was below my expectations.Appetizer:I had the the "summer salad"  lettuce with a mix radishes, heirloom tomatoes a few slices of grainy tomatoes and some anchovies . While my colleagues had the Watermelon soup( it looked interesting but they didn't like it that much) Main Course:I had the Steak which was OK, the Bordeaux spinach and potatoes were salty, bland, and just a hot mess. I felt like this was last weeks left overs. the blue cheese and the potatoes almost tasted rancid.Dessert:Nothing special to talk about( Creme Brulee, Brownie with ice cream were just average)I really did not enjoy the food here the Customer service was great and the location is  conveniently located but I will maybe give it one more chance, just not order from the Restaurant Week Menu.

Wow!  Wow, wow!  My mom and I came to 21 Club for lunch during restaurant week and wow!  It was amazing.  We were one of the first guests for lunch in the dining area and were greeted by many impeccably dressed waitors!  It definitely felt like we were in the boys' club...  The decorations on the ceiling were just something... very unique and very creative.  It brought a playful atmosphere to such an esteemed restaurant.Now onto the food... it was amazing!  I had the salmon as my main course and my mom had the steak.  Both were delicious!  And the dessert was fabulous too... I had a coconut chocolate fudge ice cream and she had the creme brulee.We had such a wonderful dining experience.  The tables are a bit crowded and they will seat you at an unusual angle (next to each other versus across) which is a little odd but it works in there for some reason.  Another thing we loved was the dress code.  Everyone looked so polished and put-together.  You don't often find that during dining experiences.Yes, it was expensive, even during restaurant week, but it was worth every penny.  We had such a nice experience on our very fun girls' weekend.Next time we're in NYC, we would love to come back!  I know my husband would love it.

Lovely place, awesome service. However, the food is just okay. I went there for the restaurant week promotion. Maybe they didn't put the chief's best dish on the menu - I'll only give 3/5 for the food, and i don't think i would pay the regular price for the quality.
Classic atmosphere, rich history. Good place for special occasions. Nothing wowing in the food.

I wanted so badly to fall madly in love with the 21 club, but the ultra formal decor was just so drastically at odds with the medicore food. Tiny but super expensive portions of food that you could find identically at more mid-range restaurants made my visit here an exciting novelty into the world of "classic" NY landmarks, but definitely not a regular stop. On the whole I would definitely have to echo the reviews below--great to visit once, but not necessarily worth making the regular list.

A perfect example of why restaurant week can be a disaster. Total mismatch - extraordinary atmosphere, mediocre food.This place is like stepping on to a movie set. It's stuffy and old-school; the waiters scurry about in their white jackets as titans of industry and the women who love them plan their next takeover. Sports memorabilia and model planes, trains and automobiles dangle from the low ceiling. I sat down ready to make some deals and eat some meat.Things started out promising - a plate of oysters were fresh, briny, and well-accompanied. But then, I ordered from the restaurant week menu. Mistake. I know that a RW menu is not going to be the top-notch offering at a restaurant (I mean, its $24, that is not a lot to work with), but it should at least be a good-faith effort. The "summer salad" was a modified verison of the one on the menu - reduced to a bag of spring mix and some radishes. The heirloom tomatoes with creamy parmesan sauce? A few slices of grainy tomato with some lettuce, a few droopy anchovies and (sad, sad, sad) no creamy parmesan to be found. Steak was fine, but "bordeaux spinach" and potatoes were salty, bland, and disappointing. Dessert was really no better than Hot & Crusty.RW is a great way to get people into your restaurant, but don't you want them to come back and order the real thing? I did have fun here, which keeps me from giving a 1 or 2 star review, but there has to be a way to do better even within the constraints of RW. The 21 Club is an institution that has been and will be around for a long time. If the RW selection is going to be so unimpressive, maybe just don't do it and stick to what works.

Service was great, but food was meh. The grilled octopus was overcooked and way too salty (although it was my fault for ordering octopus at this type of establishment). Salmon was edible but nothing special. Food was underwhelming but I assume the animal meat there would be better. I don't think it's a place for pescatarians or health conscious eaters.
Good classic place. Enjoy the Remingtons on the wall and the ambiance.

I came here on my birthday before heading over to the theatre to enjoy their pre-fixe menu.  The service was excellent, although the tables were a bit cramped and the food was good, but excellent. The atmosphere was pretty cool, with toys and such plastered all over the walls (this sounds weird, but it worked).  I've since seen 21 Club in a few movies, and can now identify it. It won't be a go-to place,  but it was worth the one visit.

As a dyed-in-the-wool New Yorker, I generally try to avoid touristy establishments.  However, there are a few instances where the establishment draws a tourist crowd, yet it is still worthy of attention.  An interesting atmosphere, consistently good menu or even a long standing reputation can tip the scales in favor of one of these places.One week ago, I found myself perusing locales for a celebratory dinner and had a hard time sorting through the high quality restaurants that are in abundance in New York.  Aside from having an interesting menu, my number one criteria was that the restaurant had to be memorable.  I wanted a place that was distinctively New York.  Even more specifically, old school New York, of which very few places still remain.  This line of thought led me to the 21 Club.In the Hitchcock film Rear Window, Grace Kelly brings Jimmy Stewart take-out from the 21 Club, which watching it as a child burned the name into my consciousness and created an allure that has remained with me to this day.  So it was definitely the 21 Club for that special evening.It had been at least two decades since the last time I had dined at the 21 Club, so I wasn't sure if it would hold up to my memories.  We were seated in the downstairs dining room, a room where the ceiling is decorated with hanging sports helmets, model trucks and airplanes, adding a bit of whimsy to what is a rather formal atmosphere.I began my meal with a chopped salad consisting of savoy cabbage, romaine, bell peppers, snow peas, zucchini, garbanzos with a white balsamic dressing.  My partner began with an appetizer of lump crab served on radicchio, with grape tomatoes, celery and lettuce.  Both appetizers were light and refreshing, setting the palate for the main course to come.As a first time guest at 21, my partner had to try the 21 Burger, served with melted cheddar cheese, tomato, frisée, haricots verts and carmelized onions.  Skeptical that the burger could live up to its $32 price tag, he dug into his meal and proclaimed that it was most likely the best burger he had ever had and it was cooked to perfection.  He especially liked the bourbon ketchup sauce that they served as part of the condiments.  I would have to agree about the bourbon ketchup as I managed to swipe several fries and dipped them in the sauce.  Super tasty!For my main course, I had the Vegetable Tasting, consisting of a portobello mushroom tower with a light cream sauce, stuffed red peppers and a vegetable quinoa.  The dish was delicious, scoring extra points for creativity.  I was also impressed with the vegetable quinoa, considering that most restaurants when offering a vegetarian item on the menu completely overlook the fact that some type of protein is needed in the meal.We ended the meal with a Chocolate Griottine Torte that was divine! Regrettably, I was so taken with the smooth and decadent chocolate torte with brandied cherries and sour cream ice cream, that I completely forgot to take a picture until the plate was cleaned.  Despite having no photo, it is definitely etched into my memory.The 21 Club lived up to its image and was the perfect place to create memories for our celebratory occasion.  As fewer and fewer of the old New York establishments remain, it is somehow comforting that the 21 Club is still there, still quality and still able to transport you back to a New York rich with history.For Photos with the review go to:ladieswholunchtravel.blo…

Top notch service. Interesting atmosphere. There is sort of an old-school / boy's-club / professional environment with a ton of history feel to it. Something you might find at a steakhouse or something. The decor is hard to ignore - from floor to ceiling. There is a lot of "stuff" to soak in when you walk in the dining area.My party of 3 enjoyed the pre-theatre pre-fixe dinner menu. We had the asparagus, salad, salmon, and creme brulee. The starters were good. The white asparagus might have been the most interesting dish. The salad was light and tasty. The salmon I thought was too close to medium for me - I would have prepared more medium rare. It wasn't really memorable - not extraordinarily tasty or fresh. The creme brulee was a little too creamy for my liking. Even though it was a pre-fixe menu and considered very affordable for midtown NY standards, I thought it was a little overpriced for what it was. It didn't wow me.I was more impressed with the atmosphere, service, and decor than I was with the food. I would say the food was more 3-stars and everything else was 4-stars.

Came here for a birthday dinner and we pulled out all the stops. Service was wonderful and the atmosphere was surprisingly comfortable. My lamb was possibly the best lamb I've ever had - I traded samples for the 28 day dry aged sirloin and filet mignon and thought my lamb was better ;) Perfectly seasoned and juicy. Started with the deviled egg (note singular noun) with lobster - pretty tasty but not really worth $19. The cheese plate was quite excellent with the dried fruit and jams; desserts were good but not outstanding. Overall, good food and service but a bit overpriced (I would've been disappointed if I ordered one of the steaks).

Definitely an institution like place that seems to wield a lot of power.  I definitely felt out of place looking at everyone around me and seeing how old they are, but I never felt uncomfortable.  The food here is pretty good and you really can't go wrong except for a couple dishes.Sweetbreads - super crunchy and fried to perfection, loved everything that came with this dishRoasted lobster - tender and sweet, cooked perfectly, can't go wrong with this as an entreeGrass fed beef carpaccio - delicious, again, can't go wrong with this starterbeef tartar - again very good and irony.  they allow you to choose how spicy you want it which is a nice touch21 Burger - I realize they're suppose to be famous for this burger, but I'd definitely give this one a pass, a lot of better burgers in the city that's less than this oneChocolate Souffle - Pass on this, too.  Hardly fluffy and not very light.Overall a great experience.  If you're a male, remember to speak to Poverty in the bathroom, if you're having a bad day, he'll make it better.  If you're having a good day, he'll make you feel even better.  Remember to ask for a tour after dinner, too.  They have one hell of a wine collection.****

This is one cool place. It is definitely only for special occasions, unless you have a lot of cash to spend. Although the place is quite fancy and special, the decor is very casual but in a great way. The tables are covered with picnic-like red and white checkered table cloths and from the ceiling hangs toys and other trinkets (like real signed helmets!) that they've gathered from their famous and important guests over the years (picture included). My boyfriend and I had made reservations for the upstairs room since I wasn't a fan of the decor from the website. They called a few days before to ask if we minded being seated in the bar room and offered us a free bottle of champagne for the inconvenience. I'm so glad that we got to experience the bar room and they gave us one of the nicest champagne bottles on the menu - not necessary at all! Especially since we are 25 and clearly not as picky as the other patrons. (E.g., the table next to us was filled with middle aged men in matching suits having a debate about which black card is best.) Although I didn't love my entre (the seafood platter), the food overall was great! I highly recommend the game tasting platter, which my boyfriend got. My boyfriend also loved the place so much that he asked to see their private dining room in case he wanted to throw an event there. Although I didn't love the private dining room, it was SUPER cool to see. It was the place that served as their speakeasy during prohibition. They've preserved the mayor's table from then while updating the rest of the room. You also get to see their wine cellar, which is used by celebrities and other important people for their private collections (pictures included).

Forgot to mention Reverend Lorenzo Robinson, the bathroom attendant (yes, there are still some of those in posh establishments like this).  Here is a link to a newspaper article about him:nysun.com/on-the-town/re…I think it was my first fascinating conversation in a bathroom... ever.
The perfect mix of old school charm and delicious food. Ask for a tour of the wine cellar.

Recently wen to NYC and dined at 21 Club before seeing The Lion King.   The staff was top notch, the atmosphere was hip yet with lots of old nostalgia, the story of it's history during Prohibition was interesting!  The portion sizes were  smaller than I would have liked but probably the size we should all eat.  The staff made sure we had plenty of time to get to the show by asking where and what time the show was.  I would definitely make this a stop while in NYC!

21 Club was fantastic! I went there tonight for a private event, and the food was delicious. The salad, pretty much just lettuce, tomato, and celery, was one of the best I've eaten despite its simplicity. The steak was cooked to perfection, and the cheesecake came with cinnamon apples that really spiced it up. Perhaps the best part of the evening was the service! Our server Raul was seriously one of the nicest I've ever had. Even though it was a private event, I felt like I got very personal attention, and despite lots of people ordering things left and right, he always remembered my special requests. I wish I could have given him an extra tip, but unfortunately I couldn't find him at the end of the dinner. At any rate, this restaurant has great food with great service, and I highly recommend it for a nice evening out!

Another perfect NY moment, well where to begin...ok first off let me say this will be the first of many visits. We were welcomed and seated at the bar where we  were instantly introduced to some of the regulars, the first being Gill,  he was a charming gentleman with an twinkle of mischief in his eye, my kinda man.  Then we asked about the history of this establishment and quickly realized this was an amazing place with a rich new york stories vibe,  that is adapting to the nowaday trends while keeping the spirit alive.  The place is filled with traditions, take a tour of the main room and you can see the great trickets left behind as momentos.  On my first tour Eddie showed me the model planes  left by the likes of  Howard Hughes, Clinton and other memorablilia from JFK and even some published books by Said Gill. Ok I'll admit that after a few cocktails the tour may require a repeat visit to remember details...especially Eddie's all in cocktails....lord can he pour, god bless him!  But the bottom line is that I like places where you can hear stories both past and present, about why everyone likes hanging out there.  The place looks like it might be a private, members only place but as they say "while they do have a dress code anyone is welcomed" and they take this theme to the next level and make you feel both welcomed and happy.  Do yourself a favor and plan a vist and you too will fall to the charm of the 21 Club,See you there on my futur visites to NY.....p.s.  I had the chance to meet a lot of the people working there, everyone from the hostess, the maitre d, waiters, managers, ladies room attendant, and doorman and each and everyone was charming and authentically friendly and loving what they do, real pros all around.

Do you know why they are so exclusive, have been around forever and are an institution? Because they ARE New York and are great at it.The food is wonderful (veal, fish, duck... everything is cooked to perfection).  The service is what you would expect of a place of this caliber (attentive, helpful and your water glass is never half full).  And they are always up to give you a tour of the infamous hidden cellar (you have to go... its one of the classic hidden gems in this city). Of course, that means prices are gong to be extravagant.  But, just make sure you know that going into it.Honestly, I can't think of somewhere that represents this city better than 21.  GO!

These guys just keep hitting it out of the park.  The 21 Club made a big gamble by renovating the lounge and putting in a bar.  This is an "institution" kind of place, don't rock the boat.  Heck, this is where they filmed a legendary scene in the 80's movie, Wall Street.  You don't mess with perfection, right?I popped in to the 21 Club for some drinks recently and instead of sinking into a comfy club chair, I took a seat at the new bar.  The booze was reasonably priced, the service was great, and they did a great job of adding a bar to a relatively small space and it all sort of works.... and works really well, too.

Great place for drinks and dinner with friends. The decor ivs fun and exciting and makes the place interesting.  Drinks are a bit expensive , but hey it is new York city what do you expect.  They should have a ladies hour then would love th place.  I would go again just after I get. Paycheck to afford this place.

So I was meeting my girlfriend up for a Broadway show and we didn't really make any dinner plans.  Being that it was restaurant week a quick search of menus we finally settled on 21 club.  When we arrived the first thing the host asked us which name we had our reservations under.  We didn't have reservations so we ended up getting a table at the bar.  The restaurant is definitely geared towards the WASPs in the city and has that kind of smoking room old boy's club feel.  Apparently plenty of famous people have eaten here as the bathroom attendant informed me.  Service at this restaurant is on par with what I would expect with a place of this caliber.  It was however not as good as my standard bearer at Gordon Ramsey's restaurant.  The food was delicious, well portioned, and definitely not the small plates you would see at some of the fine dining establishments.  I would definitely come back to this restaurant again as everything was delicious.  Word of warning, men do have to wear jackets.

Great place to go for drinks.  I had a martini ($14) and my girlfriend had a Manhattan ($15) (yep, she's a keeper).  Both drinks were perfect.  For the martini, they asked whether I wanted gin or vodka, and which type of vodka I preferred.  Our server came back quite frequently (but very unobtrusively) to spruce up the table, and asked each of us how we liked our drinks.They had a fire burning in the fireplace, and at one point my girlfriend took a sip of her Manhattan, and the server took away her cocktail napkin and slid a new one in its place.As others have said, the bathroom attendants are all great conversationalists.More than worth it for the prices.  I loved it, and look forward to my next visit.

Definite disappointment.  I went with my parents and fiance last night to celebrate my birthday.   No restaurant week or special theater menu, we went for the real deal.I used the restroom right before being seated and the bathroom attendant was probably the best part of the entire evening.  She was so sweet, kind and the type of person you just want to hug.  The rest is downhill.Whilst I can appreciate the fact that 21 Club is a NY institution, I don't think that it warrants the poor service or mediocre cuisine that we experienced.  We waited quite a while after receiving our menus to have someone come by to take our order or ask if we had any questions (which only happened after my father had to signal someone to come over).  His drink was empty well before then and no one had even noticed (serious party foul).  No one mentioned any specials and our waiter simply kept saying how everything was "amazing" and "the best."   Errrr...not so much buddy.I had the carpaccio to start, my mother the beet salad and my father the crab appetizer.  None were anything special or particularly tasty.  For entrees my father had the burger, my mother the salmon trout, my fiance the chicken hash and myself the filet mignon.  All quite sub-par and disappointing, particularly the chicken hash which is supposed to be a "signature" dish.  Just a matter of cutting up some chicken pieces, pouring over them a creamy sauce and melting some Gruyere cheese on top.  We shared the apple crumb pie for dessert which was decent.All in all, the lack of attention to our table and the less-than-average food served to contribute to an average evening which cost us way more than it was worth.Kudos on the $5 parking and the bathroom attendant.  That's unfortunately all I can really say stood out.  Note:  We did eat downstairs, not sure if much is different in the upstairs dining room but, this experience didn't exactly make me want to come back to try it out.

One of the best places to go before a show. Can't beat their 5 dollar parking deal for 6 hours! The 21 Club Burger is delicious as always, clearly they are a NYC institution for a reason. Their service is second to none. Make sure to try their special for the day - that always seems to be a sure bet. On this last trip is was lamb and it was incredible.

The famed 21 Club lived up to my expectation during Rest-Week.  Service was superb all around.  Food was outstanding.  Very hot when being served.  Seafood was superb.  Port Chop was very tender.  Superb location.  Central to all.  Will go there again for sure.  Very impressed.

Jackets required.  Well..  I sorta expected a bit more from a place with that type of requirement, but then again...  its an old establishment.Food - not bad.  I had the set menu for lunch.  Food was good.  Cooked and presented well.  The ambience is too formal for me.   Good place to talk business, but not a place to relax and enjoy as it is just too formal.

The 21 Club is a New York institution. With all the modern day speakeasy crazes that are going on around the city, to which I won't deny attending a few, this place is one of the originals dating back to the Prohibition era that still retains its class to this day.I've eaten here on two occasions. The first was was with my girlfriend on December 31, 2009. We dined upstairs and it was quite elegant. The menu was an extremely reasonable $70-something per person, which was a great deal for NYE in NYC and at the 21 Club. The host of upstairs and his staff were extremely attentive and accommodating. When my gf was cold, he got her a shawl and when he saw me looking around the room, he came over and asked what my I was trying to figure out, which was the seating capacity of the room. He even escorted my girlfriend to that bathroom at one point.The food itself was quite delicious as well. Since the dinner was a while ago, I can't remember our appetizers at all. I have a picture of my gf's main course, but can't remember what it was, other than a seafood dish. For my main course, I had the Mixed Grill of Game, prepared rare. This dish was an antelope chop, Millbrook venison loin, homemade rabbit sausage, bacon-wrapped Mangalitsa pork loin, carrot purée, ginger chutney, huckleberry sauce. Yum, yum and yum. For dessert, I had the Pain Perdu, which was also delicious. Can't remember my gf's dessert at this point... I know it's not helpful for the review, sorry.All in all tho, the food was very well prepared and served. High marks for presentation and taste.The second time I was here was for Restaurant Week, Summer 2011. I brought some of my friends along and there were eight of us in all. Upon arriving, we sat in the lounge first, as we waited for #8 to arrive. Service in the bar is very professional and respectful, tho don't be surprised by the cost of drinks. One of my friends who can't have alcohol drank a Cranberry & Seltzer for around $6 or $7. I had a Remy Sidecar which ran $18.After friend #8 arrived, we were escorted to our table. As it was Restaurant Week, we ate in the Bar Room, which is a completely different atmosphere than upstairs. Since the reservation was in my name, I walked to the matire'd and asked to be seated. Before showing us in, he insisted on taking my drink from me and bringing it to the table for me. Nice touch. After being seated, the wait staff was equally as friendly, polite and professional. We were all addressed as Mister, Sir, or Gentleman.Anyways, on to the food, which I'm sorry to say wasn't as good as when I dined upstairs. For my appetizer, I had the Grilled Calamari, which came with a fava bean purée, marinated cherry tomatoes, lemon and oba leaf roasted bell pepper emulsion. I had expected the calamari to be fried as usual, but they were not fried at all... of course, since the menu did say grilled. The calamari were a pleasant surprise and not bad at all. For my main course, I had the Seafood Pasta, which was decent... nothing special. The seafood wasn't chewy or dry, but the dish overall lacked a good flavor. It also wasn't presented very neatly and looked thrown together. Between the whole table, we ordered everything on the menu and everyone else really seemed to enjoy their food.For dessert, I had the Peach and Apricot Streusel Tart with sour cream ice cream. The peaches used in this dessert were donut peaches. The dessert sounded very promising, but was a bit of a letdown. The ice cream, peaches and top of the streusel were quite good, but the sides and bottom of the streusel were sort of rock hard. Would I come back here? Probably. I'd like to try their burger at some point, tho I have made the recipe at home (yes, I got the proper amounts of kinds of meat, including short ribs). Before trying to make the 21 Burger at home, I was doing a little online research and noted that someone who ate the 21 Burger made in-house said it tasted a bit like meatloaf. Having made the burger at home, I can second that.This place is a cool to check out during Restaurant Week. The staff is very friendly and professional and you can tell a lot of the waiters have been there for a long time. The Bar Room has a very cool atmosphere with all its decorations, but is quite loud as well.For a much better experience at 21, eat upstairs for a special occasion. You won't be disappointed.

RW menu. 5:30 reservation on a friday. pretty quiet- no background music for ambiance. Service was great, besides the first waiter that never presented us with a menu (i think he was annoyed that I didnt know what i wanted to drink the moment i was seated). he was pretty old school- no amount of charm or smiles would soften his Lurch-like disposition. otherwise, the rest of the staff was kind and attentive.The food: Tuna tartar- refreshing.Soup (Manhattan clam chowder)- had to convince my date not to lift the bowl for the last sips.Pork loin- portion was WAY larger than i was anticipating. pork cooked perfectly (side note: nothing annoys me more than overcooked protein). brussel sprouts were my favorite part. the sauce wasnt that special but still a very good plate of food.Seafood pasta- boyfriend said it was good, but nothing too out of the ordinary. unlike what  previous posts have claimed, there was plenty of large shrimp, scallops, and squid (which, he claimed, "were nothing like rubber bands" :) )Creme brule- delicious! Key lime- exceptionally tangy. The strawberry compote on the side definitely kicks up the sweetness factor so use wisely.They gave us a plate of mini dessert as well- 2 mini chocolate macaroons and 2 chocolate (white and dark) confections.Overall- this place was a joy. with food and drink $150+ So that puts into perspective the pricetag of this place on a normal day. However, here, you get what you pay for.Warning: if you arent willing to embrace "old new york" fine dining, stay away.  otherwise, you might wrongfully misconstrue the staffs behavior as pompus or uppity, thus putting a damper on your evening. the truth is that some places take their service very seriously, but that doesnt mean you have to. :)

It's only appropriate that I begin my review of 21 Club with a notorious quote from the indomitable Groucho Marx:"I don't want to belong to any club that will accept people like me as a member."Ok, it's not really a club but it's a landmark that has been frequented by legends of the screen, captains of industry and just about everyone in between. And for three glorious hours I felt like a member of a private club, receiving white glove service (Literally. The white gloved bathroom attendant joked that fellow yelper in crime Benson Y and I were taking the spots belonging to Warren Buffet and Bill Gates.) While 21 earned notoriety during the roaring 20's when Prohibition reigned supreme (Such an uncivilized time when vices were illegal...) , the repeal of the 18th amendment means you can legally drink here again. 23 skidoo!The complimentary bar munchables were quite good, roasted nuts and such. There's a fireplace! With real fire! The 1% and restaurant week 99% never had it so good.Led into the dining room, turn your head upwards. No, it's not rude and you'll be treated to a panoply of toys and memorabilia. A Cincinnati Reds hat from Pete Rose, a walmart truck donated by Sam Walton, and plenty of other corporate swag. Apparently this tradition dates back to when British Airways donated a toy, it was mounted and the rest is history. (Perhaps bars that feature womens' undergarments in similar positions share a spiritual bond with 21?)Anyway, our waiter was all too happy to explain ,with ease, the menu and the historical importance of our table.I like places that have such cachet but I also like places that deliver the goods, food-wise.No problems here as the regular menu offering of a mixed grilled wild game platter was expertly explained and carved by our waiter. He even name dropped where 21 purchases such exotic cuts as antelope. At $46, it cost more than a regular prix fixe resto week for one but here's what it contained:antelope chop, Millbrook venison loin, homemade rabbit sausage, bacon-wrapped Mangalitsa pork loin, carrot purée, ginger chutney, huckleberry sauce .How could one possibly refuse? 8 people were able to amply share a bit of each piece. I'd return just for this plate alone.Regaining fiscal sanity, I ordered from the restaurant week menu and started with the salmon tartare, served with taro chips. And as a stand alone appetizer this was quiet good but I must be brutally honest. It didn't have a chance next to the mixed grilled wild game platter (MGWGP). The taro chips were crunchy and were a fine complement to the salmon tartare, serving as a reminder of what healthy eating could be as I gorged upon rabbit sausage, feeling the blood lust du lapin.Time for a breather and a glass of malbec, recommended by ever helpful waiter.Resume feasting.Up next, Coffee-Chili Rubbed Pork Loin with sweet potato purée, chestnuts, roasted Brussels sprouts and  Oaxaca chocolate sauce.This was easily one of the juiciest pork loins I've ever had in my loin consuming career, the kind of loin that should make pig eaters across the world unite and realize that pork is so much more than the other white meat.And hats off to brussels sprouts for these veggie orbs were also flavorful, especially when dipped into oaxaca chocolate sauce.The chocolate sauce was more savory than sweet, serving as a transition to dessert, the flourless chocolate torte with peanut rum sauce and chantilly cream.It's as if Captain Morgan put a little captain in a bottle of Skippy.The peanut rum sauce was by far the distinguishing characteristic of an otherwise par for the course flourless chocolate torte. The peanut rum sauce pushes the rank over the edge of four stars and into five star heaven.So our crew of intrepid eaters, occupying a table that has  seated the incumbent president, Hilary Clinton and Dag Hammerskjold back in the day (Daaag!) staggered out well fed and ready for a return trip.Gents, wear a jacket please. No jeans or sneakers. Ladies, bring a sugar daddy, or so my keen eye observed surveying other tables in the crowd. Everyone, bring your appetite, appreciation of old new york, and a tip for the bathroom attendant.

Restaurant Week provided the perfect excuse to drop in to 21 Club.  The atmosphere and bar was great and the food was below average.  Because my ratings ultimately are weighted by food quality, I cannot give a glowing overall rating.The positives, however, are: 1) the bar-- offering $3.50 six-ounce pours of beer, $7 French Sauvignon Blanc, spacious seating and complimentary bar nibbles, provides a great clubby backdrop for a relatively (an unexpected) inexpensive drink or two. If I was a "cocktail hour" guy, which I am not, this would be a good go-to spot.2) the dining room aesthetic- the toy collection dangling from the ceiling is neat, whimsical and kitschy, and much better than the standard and tired caricature murals of famous patrons at similar NYC institutions.3) the servers were attentive and pleasant.  Except for the bumbling attendant who kept trolling the bar calling out whose reservation had come due.  He asked us at least four times if we were with four different parties.The food is almost not even worth mentioning.  The pasta with shrimp, red-pepper sauce and calamari was bland and terrible.  Bottled Prego would have been a step up.  The salmon tartare was indistinguishable and oily.  The creamed cauliflower soup was average at best.  The spiced (coffee-chili rubbed) pork loin with brussels sprouts and sweet potato was good- particularly the pork; however its accoutrements failed in terms of execution and were essentially tasteless.  The desserts were the highlight.  The key lime tart was actually quite good and the mint-chocolate sundae was not bad.

We had a great time there during restaurant week. Great service, good food (not increddible but tasty and good size portions), and even extra gifts from our waiter. Loevely in all aspects. Be back soon.

This is one of my go-to places for afterwork drinks and a bite. They have one of the best bartenders in New York, who can mix up all sorts of magic potions, based on one's specifications.The staff is accommodating and friendly and the food is pas mal. The overall atmosphere is warm.Though if it did not sometimes feel like a father-knows-best- sausage-fest, I would give it an extra star.

Dear 21 Club: If you're going to actively suck at RW, you just shouldn't do it at all.  I guess there are two veins of thoughts on Restaurant Week from a restaurant's point of view.  One (which I like) is that it's a great way for restaurants to drum up business - let people try out places that they would like to come back to on a special occasion, get some word of mouth going.  Two (which I don't) is that these restaurants are doing us a favor by just letting us in the door.  21 Club was very much of the second view.  They have a strict dress code, no jeans, no sneakers and blazers required for the boys.  Restaurant Week patrons (us) were in the bar room, festooned with plastic toys dangling from the ceiling (shades of TGIF) and tables as packed as they could get them.  The cocktails at our table ranged from mediocre to terrible, with the Bees Knees (hopefully) missing some ingredients as its contents tasted almost entirely of lemon juice.  Shall we move on to the food?  Not only boring, but not very well prepared.  The grilled calamari was chewy and lukewarm.  Salmon in the salmon tartare was step in the unfresh direction.  The terrine was ok.  The chicken was dry but serviceable, kind of what you expect when you order RW chicken.  Pork was ok.  The pasta was intriguing in its weirdness. The clear winner of the evening was the chocolate torte, with a deep, complex flavor.  The creme brulee, which I thought would be the hardest to mess up for a uncaring kitchen was all cold, had the thinnest of sugar crusts that was already soggy, and slightly curdy, thin custard.  Service?  Every dish was literally just thrown on the table.  Clatter, rollllll.  Clatter, rolll. Over and over again.  I assume this was a RW special.  Not pleased.  So in conclusion, we were seriously disappointed. Could you tell?

This is what Restaurant Week is all about, going to places you can't afford in your wildest dream, with your friends!We came thru 21 Club this past Monday for a late (9pm) dinner. As you know by now, this place is classy and shmancy so you can't wear jeans and you have to wear a jacket (blazer) and shoes. No problem. No one loves getting dressed up like I do.The funny thing is, the entrance is classy, there's a bar and you can order what I would guess are expensive cocktails. We walked inside however, and it kind of had a diner feel to it. Checkerboard table cloths, and it had all these "artifacts" hanging from the ceiling, that were like model airplanes and stuff toys and things! It was very strange. Ah well. On to the food.I ordered the the grilled calamari to start. It was alright. Had a lot of different flavors going on, with these very potent olives and other things. For my main course I got the seafood pasta, which was good. It was in what I think was vodka sauce, but the actual pasta was some very huge pieces of macaroni. It was good. One of my friends got hte salmon, which he devoured so I'm assuming it was good. Another friend of mine got the pork chop, which I had a little bit of, it was good as well.For desert I got ice cream (again) which was good if you really like chocolate, which im not really a fan of. Two people got Creme Brulee (of course) and since it's Creme Brulee it was great. My other friend got their version of the Key Lime pie, which she didn't really like, siting that there wasn't enough Key lime in it. I'm not a Key Lime fan so I didn't even try a bite, I wouldn't have given it justice anyway.The food for me was alright, but I had to give it an extra star because we managed to get a tour of the secret wine cellar downstairs! So awesome. They actually keep the wines and champagnes in the same place they kept it during prohibition, in a secret airconditioned room that is only accessed by a secret door that's actually about a foot thick wall of bricks! It was like going into the Bat Cave! Once inside, you saw all the bottles that were purchased by all these celebs and politicians, who were coming back at a later date to pick it up (if they wanted). Once you go past the wine cellar you enter the private dining room, that has a huge table that stretches out and can seat a bunch of your friends. I guess they do 7 course dinners down there, but God knows how much that would set you back per person. It seems like one of those ridiculous opulent things that rich people do however, that would actually be cool to do if you had the money to do it. I can't imagine me coming back here (unless I'm rich enough to rent out that room!) but it was an awesome experience for a first-timer like myself. I love Restaurant Week!

I made reservations a few weeks beforehand and was so excited about finally coming to 21 club! I was disappointed when we were seated downstairs, I had expected we would be upstairs in the main dining room. To top things off, we were seated at a very odd two seated right up against the bar. It was just awkward.We came here before seeing a show, so we had the pre-theatre pre fixe menu, which is 3 courses for $40. Unfortunately, there wasn't much value. The menu was pretty, well, bad. I started with the salmon tartar, had the grilled salmon and ended with the chocolate tart. My boyfriend had the calamari, seafood pasta, and the creme brulee. we both had a glass of wine, which were the best parts of the meal! Overall, it was bland, lacked presentation, and the service was just awfully slow.I highly doubt I'll return. $120.00 + tip not well spent.

I came here with my fellow co-workers for restaurant week. We sat at the Bar Room. I ordered food from their Prix Fixe Luncheon menu for only $24.07 per person. The food is excellent and the service is efficient. I tried the seasoned soup, which is the Tomato Wheat. My Main Course was the Seafood Pasta; dessert is the Creme Brulee. I loved my order. The Tomato Wheat was thick; Seafood Pasta was delectable; Creme Brulee was savory!The toys on the ceiling are gifts from regulars - the airplanes and trucks are from the executives of the companies they represent, and the sports memorabilia are from owners and famous players. This place is great if you want to discuss business with your guests and/or if you want a private time with your close friends. There are 10 rooms inside the 21 club. There is a strict dress code for men. Men must wear a Jacket; no jeans or sneakers.I would come back only for lunch to try their other Prix Fixe lunch menu. It only cost $10 more or if the place offers another NYC Restaurant Week discount!

I had made reservations for Restaurant Week 2012 for 4 on a Saturday night (I realized they didn't do the Restaurant Week menu on weekends after the fact). We arrived a half hour earlier than our reservation and were seated within 5 minutes. Once seated, bread was brought to the table and menu and a wine list were given to us. I have to say that seating against the wall were a bit tight, like many other Manhattan restaurants. I have been here once before, but I never understood the decor. Classic and dimly lit, the ceiling is covered with random toys. The walls are filled with quotes and sayings referring to alcohol and drunks.When one from our group looked at the wine list and ordered a bottle of Cabernet by the number, the waiter came back saying that the number was incorrect. We looked for the correct number, but before long, the sommelier came out, looking impatient, and asked what kind of wine we were looking for. We described it by type and name and he immediately knew. Great that he knew his wine; bad that he was snooty about our choice or taste.The Restaurant Week 2012 Menu was the same as their Prix Fixe Menu, except the latter was $5 more. I had ordered the salmon tatare for my appetizer, the coffee-chili rubbed pork loin for my main course, and the key lime meringue tart for dessert. Others at the table ordered the seasonal soup, which was cauliflower soup, for the appetizer, chicken a la plancha and seafood pasta for main courses, and the flourless chocolate torte and the mint mocha sundae for desserts.Salmon tartare was delicious; taro chips were light and matched well with the fresh salmon with avocado puree. When I received the pork loin, I tasted it and it was cold. The plate was warm though. My friend had also ordered the same dish and her pork loin was cold as well. We decided to send them back. When they came back out, the plates were hot. The pork loin did not taste as good anymore. It became dry and the side of roasted brussel sprouts wilted. This seems like they put the plates in a microwave to heat them up. If that's the case, they should be ashamed. For what is supposed to be a high end restaurant, microwaving to reheat a dish is bad restaurant procedure. Quite disappointing. The Oaxaca chocolate sauce was mediocre. It was nothing to rave about. When our desserts arrived, they also brought out chocolate cookies. The chocolate cookies were smooth chocolates with a bit of raspberry and thin flaky cookies in them. Absolutely delectable. The key lime meringue tart was pleasing. Perfect amount of sweetness with a light & frothy cream. It also had a graham cracker shortbread that just melted in your mouth.I cannot say how the other dishes were, but I did try a bit of the seafood pasta. It was another disappointment. For a cream sauce, it was thin and bland. The seafood was lacking; they cut the scallops into small pieces. My friend enjoyed the cauliflower soup and chicken a la plancha, but he felt the sundae was a bit too sweet. As for the chocolate torte, it was nothing special. The cookies were so much better.I guess the main word of the night was "disappointment." I had been there in July of 2011 and the food and service were great. The people that sat next to us were lively and fun. This time, the food was a letdown. The waiters were attentive, but the sommelier was arrogant and condescending. I don't know if the quality of food was underwhelming because of Restaurant Week or the Prix Fixe Menu, but it was definitely a different experience than last year, and not in the good way.
