You cannot serve passable food if you distinguish yourself as a topnotch restaurant. If I can get better food and amazing service at a restaurant that charges less, why would I want to come back? There are many restaurants in New York, especially Manhattan, that can provide that. They need to be on top of their game if they want to continue to be a reputable restaurant.

I came here for lunch during Restaurant Week 2012. This place has an extremely old school vibe and the dress code is pretty strict -- jeans are a definite no-no. While the service was great, the food was disappointing. I had the salmon tartare and the coffee-chili rubbed pork loin, which were both pretty bland. For dessert, I got the key lime meringue tart which was overly sweet. The best thing about the meal was the thin-cut, toasted raisin bread that they serve when you first sit down.

2.5 stars. This is my type of joint- I love the homey, classy atmosphere, autographed toys and sports paraphernalia on the ceiling - but wow was table service and food-worth-the-price-tag absent this Friday night. Our server, a short black guy, stood around most of the evening doing nothing. After we were seated, he came over to take our drink orders and then ignored us for nearly ten minutes. I had to signal him to give us our menu, after doing the awkward squint stare off because I wasn't sure if he was our waiter. He was actually just standing nearby, looking at us. Super awkward. He was really inattentive, never brought the wine list, abrupt...really the pigeon poop on a good suit. The food was also surprisingly mediocre. I'm always hesitant to try the Restaurant Week menu when the dishes seem to be created just for RW. The seafood pasta barely had any seafood- two shrimp. Dos. No bueno. Pieces of one scallop. See photo. Ah well. A little bit of fresh pepper and it was ok. The salmon, which is noted on the menu to be organic (I forgot to ask if that meant wild vs farmed) was lovely but not melt in your mouth orgasmic, which is what I expected from 21 Club. We finished off the night with the creme brulee and a sundae which came out as a parfait. See pix. Both ok but I've had better brownie sundaes at chain establishments. I definitely felt like a B team was preparing those dishes. An hour later, my palate has long forgotten the dishes. The only bright spot of the night was an older waiter who noticed us taking a photo of an autographed helmet, told us the team's coach was recently in and spoke knowledgeably about some memorable games. Too bad he wasn't our server! PS the bathroom attendants in the boys and girls rooms are v friendly.

I'm a fan! My experience has been great every time I come here. Well, I know that the decor is old school and the wait can be long but I still give it a five star for the amazing wine list, great food, and great service.

The private events staff at 21 Club are true professionals.  I feel like I'm back at the Four Seasons with courteous, attentive waiters, banquet captains and event coordinators.  The servers got out of the way so we could enjoy our meal and great conversation. We dined in the 21 Club Wine Cellar which was a real treat -- a truly unique room with an old world feel and a bit of history thrown in.  It added to the chemistry of the room, and conversation flowed in what otherwise could have been a stale business dinner.  People at our table had either been there for the first time or were coming back to one of their favorite dining rooms in the city.  My only critique is that the food was over-the-top rich (caviar, foie gras) but nothing that couldn't be fixed with some changes to the menu that we selected in advance.  I will be back.

Been here several times and normally a solid experience. Not the case last night. Food - The vegetable medley was nearly stone cold. Unacceptable for a restaurant of this reputation. Burger too was only luke warm and undercooked to boot. The pork special was only fair ... nothing special at all. Caesar salad was very good as usual... same with the beet salad.Service - Disappointing. Meals were placed in front of wrong diners. Tables were packed in and one of our party was repeatedly bumped while eating by servers working other tables - inexcusable. The waiter was slow and not especially attentive and we spent a long time trying to pay the bill.We have always enjoyed 21 Club but last night it seemed just a crowded food factory and hardly the classic and classy New York restaurant we've experienced in the past.

One more important thing, which I forgot to mention before:  They added a 20% tip for themselves to our bill without asking - for a party of 4 people.  I've had the tip automatically added for parties of 6 or more, but never for 4 people.  It may have something to do with the this 30% off deal that our friends had.  To be clear, they added 20% of what the bill would have been without the discount.  I find the practice distasteful, personally.  A tip is supposed to be a reflection of service and incentive for your server to be attentive (and I am happy to pay it when I receive decent service).   Anyway, this practice may have had something to do with the poor service we experienced.

I was there with a group of five for New Year's Eve.  We had a four course dinner on the second floor, where there was a six piece jazz band.  First, our waiter was very friendly, and the staff was attentive even though this is obviously a stressful evening for any restaurant (and it was pretty full - the first floor was packed, the second floor full, and I saw people coming down from the third level all evening).Second, the food.  After a small, but not memorable (either in a good or bad way) amuse, my first course was the beet salad.  There was nothing to complain about, and it was quite good.  The second plate, consisting of Hudson Valley foie gras, was great.  My main was a fairly large and robust lamp chop, which was well-prepared and tasty.  Lastly, I had the profiteroles for dessert, and these seemed pretty standard.Everything was good, but not remarkable.  I probably wouldn't go here for a regular dinner, but for New Year's Eve it was perfectly acceptable.  The only thing that was a little weird was the music - they seemed to be playing a lot of low key or slightly somber jazz; this was very strange given that there is a large dance floor and it was New Year's Eve.  Maybe they need to reconsider their music selection for next year.  Also, the patron composition was a bit eclectic - a mix of random 30-somethings, large groups spanning two generations (ages 21-ancient), and even one couple who obviously couldn't find a baby sitter, as evidenced by the presence of their one year old plus stroller (seriously, who brings a baby to a New Year's Eve party?).I believe it was around $195 per person, exclusive of drinks, which was perfectly reasonable for what was offered.

We had a blast! It started in the bar with great drinks and great service. I don't recall the bartenders name, but he was the So Cal transplant and he made the entire group feel right at home. Dinner was great, both in room decor, food and service. The wines were presented professionally. I would definitely return to this institution.
I'm upgrading my rating.  I keep going back b/c it's such a killer spot for lunch in midtown.  Everyone appreciates the history + the revamped menu is noticeably better.

My family and I went to 21 on Christmas eve this year. I love this place and how old school and cool it is! The decor (inside and out) and even the dress of the staff all go into the complete package this place is. I'll start by saying I know Christmas Eve is a very big night for the 21 Club...we had made a reservation of 10 people over 2 months in advance and we were still sat 30 minutes late. I didn't really mind, but some of the other guests we were with are a little older and we not ok standing in the bar area for 30 minutes. When we were finally sat downstairs we were extremely hungry and ready to eat (oh except for the forgot a place setting at our table of 10)...so once we were brought another chair and setting...We all ordered drinks and a bottle of wine. The wine list is AMAZING! They also have very informative sommeliers! The server Andy ( I think) was great too. Even though we had about 4 servers throughout the meal he was very good. The food was outstanding! The menu on Christmas eve was a 3-course pre-fixe menu at something around $125. I had the crab cake and the sauteed Dover Sole. Both were the best I have ever had in my life! The dover sole came to the table de-boned which was awesome! Also, my dessert course was the homemade eggnog ice cream...seriously the best ice cream I have ever had! Ok...you must be curious why the 3 stars if everything was so great! Well, we also had some people in our party not as happy with the food. We had someone with us order a medium steak and his steak was practically rare (to rare for me and I love med rare) and it took the whole time we ate for a new steak to come out for him, making us all feel like assholes, but we didn't want our 125 dollar meals to get cold...Also, one of their picky kids sent his steak back twice, once because it had sauce on it and again because it was too rare. I guess their experiences were worse but it did affect my meal and the overall experience. I would go back... Maybe with a smaller and less picky crowd.

cool history , type of place you go when your in your forties and already made your first 100 Mil, alot of older people with younger mistresses etc :) cool place actually quite a friendly crowd, however service when we sat down wasnt good and food was average, but its type of place that drinks and fun can be had without eating here,.

You know that classic movie scene where the boy from the wrong side of the tracks falls for the uptown girl and tries to prove his worth by going to a fancy dinner with her family, only to be humiliated by being forced to wear the house blazer?  Yeah, that happened to me.   Well, sort of.Let me first add some context here.  I am not by any means financially insecure, nor was I unaware of what this place is all about.  I was well aware of the restaurant's elegance and I have a handful of suits I gladly would have worn.  But, of course, I used Savored.com to book a reservation and they only put 'no sneakers or jeans' on the receipt.   So I ended up eating with a black jacket four sizes too large for me that was a nice compliment to my navy pants.   More to come on Savored.  With that...Lesson #1: WEAR A GODDAMN JACKET!What more is there really to say about 21 Club that hasn't already been said?  It is one of the finest classic dining experiences I've had.  Bare in mind, though, that this is a classic experience in every sense of the word.  You will not get your courses back-to-back or quickly.  You will be hungry.  And, make no mistake about it, they do this on purpose.  Time is taken in between courses and orders to ensure proper preparation and to foster conversation between guests.  So, with that...Lesson #2: If you're hungry beforehand, eat a SMALL snack.  If you're in a rush, go to the ABP down the street.As far as food goes, this place had some incredibly tasty stuff.  The show-stealer for us was the Steak Tar tare.  It comes out looking like they just unwrapped it from the meat aisle at the grocery store, but, damn, does that raw pile of hamburger helper taste good.  I couldn't even begin to tell you what's in it.  Just try it.  So flavorful and great on the rye toast they provide.Fillet Mignon and oysters were both solid picks, but nothing to write home about.  They were perfectly prepared and presented,  but they didn't quite have their own spin on these dishes.  And, at 21 Club's level, they should.  All-in-all a New York must.  It's one of the last fleeting glimpses of Old New York and truly a special place to take someone you care about (or want to impress).  A quick MONEY SAVING TIP:- Go on Savored.com and book a reservation.  It will automatically take 30% off the bill (including an automatically assigned 20% gratuity).- Go to 21club.com and buy a gift card before Christmas this year.  They are 20% off as well!  (e.g. a $200 value gift card costs $160).Both of these methods can be used in conjunction with each other and ended up saving me over $100 on a "pull-out-all-the-stops" dinner for two.  You're welcome.

I have eaten at 21 every year for 10 years.I was so disappointed tonight, mainly because of the table next to us being loud and obnoxious and the waiter would not do anything  about it. I asked that the waiter ask the man behind my husband move his chair so  they were  not touching.This type of diner and the screaming ladies ordering lots of booze  should have been in a private room or not at all After dinner my husband spoke to the manager who was very condescending to us. There were lots of' men without jackets in the bar and dining room No hookers in the ladies room tonight however.It was just an uncomfortable evening for $800'..party of 4.The french 75 cocktail was perfect. my salmon was ok, salad excellent, creme brule  great. Two of us found the steak  tartar overwhelming and ate a small amount.the wine selection $300. lovely.I enjoy the 21 club recipes and cookbook at home. The audience obnoxious .the. Waiters/sommelier,managers/ should control that try to set the tone . I am sure we were not the only ones annoyed by this particular party. We  expect that  the restaurants objective is that  every diner have a great time in this interesting (fun ceiling) atmosphere. it did not happen. Never again..

Snobby, but kinda cool.  The place is dark and very cozy.  Our waiter was also a little snobby but the food was good!   The smoked pork belly was very good!  The sirloin entree was soooo tasty!   For dessert, the cheese plate was very fresh.  But do know they still bring you a small plate of cookies too.  Also fresh and homemade!We would definitely go back!

Old school charm and elegance. I believe I lowered the median age by at least 20 years.The food is very good, but not great.  Best crab cake of my life, but at $32 for a single cake, it better be. My dining companion (business lunch) had the chicken hash which he claimed was remarkable.  Rice pudding for dessert was just ok.  Excellent service and a feeling you're peeking into a rarefied New York world with captains of industry and retired captains lunching with their ladies, many of whom appear quite high end.  The waiter reminded me of something out of a classy 1940s film noir.I likely won't be back, but glad I tried it (and glad my business companion picked up the rather hefty lunch tab as was able to expense it).

Went here during Restaurant Week, which, if I'm paying, is the only time I can afford it.  The food and service were both very good.  Gentlemen, please do not try to remove your jacket, even if it's 85 degrees in the restaurant, or you will get yelled at.  In fact, if you ever need something, the quickest way to get a waiter over to your table would probably be to take off your jacket.

Place was interesting. They had a variety of novelty toys hanging from the ceiling which include hard hats, boats and trailer trucks. I had the sea bass with shrimp. It was delicious! Ran into Commissioner Kelly in the bathroom. Awkward. After dinner, we asked to tour the cellar. It was pretty awesome. The door was 2 tons. This is definitely a must.

I had a fun time here!  Two gentlemen greeted us when we walked in, and they have the cutest matchbooks with toy soldiers on the covers.Food was decent and well-prepared, and the service was excellent.  I loved the decor and furnishings; it was embellished with an antique theme complete with little toys ranging from airplanes to Ford-esque automobiles hanging festively from the ceilings.

Worst food I have ever had!  My husband and I are vegetarian and decided to go during restaurant week.  We called ahead and they assured us they can make a vegetarian pasta.  We ended up getting a bland, watery pasta.  It was disgusting.  When the waiter came by to ask if everything was ok, I had to ask for red pepper, black pepper, salt, parmesan and garlic to make it edible.  It was absolutely tasteless! How can such an expensive and prestigous restaurant screw up a simple pasta dish??  My husband was furious and spoke to the manager who did nothing.  Afterwards, he wrote a letter to them to which he got a response that they were sorry about our experience.  That was it!  Maybe the meat and seafood is good there but if you're vegetarian, don't bother.  It's a total waste.

This place was recommended by a friend. We were a group of 4 people and ate the bar. What a fun experience! Great ambience, great food and great service. Will definitely go back. The reason I give it four stars and not five is because the lady at the reception who made our dinner reservation was so utterly rude. Almost thought of canceling the reservation and going elsewhere.

This is the best place i had ever been to. It's very expensive though.The place was dark and dimmed. The food was very unique and yet very tasty.    My friend and i went upstairs to have diner. even though it was way more expensive, but it was all worth it. The wine was very good and my steak was unbelievable.The only downfall for this place is that you have to dress with at suit and jacket. If not dressed in a business fashion they wont let you in.   All i can say if your in midtown please go. This place is a must. As emeril lagasse siting down on the first floor which was an amazing experience for me it was all worth it. The best early birthday gift for me so far. I would go again.
One of the best places to eat in the world i think.Food is excellent every time I have went.I had my 21st Birthday here and it was the best experience of my life.

Gentlemen, wear a jacket. My friend failed to do so, and they refused entry. However, they do you have a rack of jackets, that my friend got to "borrow." It didn't fit him well, and he looked silly, but oh well, should have worn a jacket!The service, decor, lighting, ambience, etc are all 5 stars. If you choose to go upstairs for the more private and expensive dining experience, it's amazing. However, the downstairs area is wonderful as well.The food was impressive, but not enough to be blown away. If you want, they have a pre-fixe theater menu, which was what my friend chose before we went to watch the Adams Family.If anything, I would return for the location, the food can wait.

This place was recommended by Ben aka social media man. And was a fantastic recommendation. First of all, the food and decor was legendary. The meal was filling, tasty, and plated nicely. The ambiance had that nostalgia feel to it - random objects hanging from the ceiling (was that a doll's head?). Then why the 4 stars instead of 5? The snooty-a** service. SOB. Seriously, I wanted to give this place 3 1/2 stars. These people think we owe them a favor for coming in. Phuck that. Seriously, phuck that. Sigh. I'm aggravated as heck. Any who: Restaurant week - the only really decent restaurant on that list. Pork loin dish - the sauce with green beans? Epic. Grilled calamari? Eh - needs a little work. Salmon with couscous ? Phuck yeah! Desert? Nothing out of the ordinary. *Guys - wear a jacket or don't come at all. They are serious about their dress code. *20% tip required.

I went here on a date. The service was impeccable. The food was average for the price which is to say very good, but not an exceptional value. The place has a lot of history and charm. Apparently it has a very loyal regular following of business executives whose corporate swag line the ceiling of the dining room.

The history of the 21 club is very interesting and while dinning there you really feel a part of it.   They have some really interesting gifts hung on their ceiling.Dinning there is really an experience.  There will always be great service and great wines to choose from, but the comfort food is not impressive.  I would suggest going here in the winter to have a meal that will keep you warm all night.

If you're looking for a historical, fancy, New Yorky, place to eat then this is definitely the way to go! It was the perfect place to take a work colleague on her last day. Celebratory, cozy and memorable. Given the prices are a bit steep, I was able to get the 3 course meal for only $25. What I liked:- the decor (the waiter explained to us that each company gave a "toy" with their brand when they visited, so that all those companies are being represented in that historical place!)- the staff. Impeccable service! We were just 2 young gals, but they still treated us like royalty.- the non-pushing to drink wine or alcohol. We actually asked for the wine list but it was too overwhelming. When we decided not to order any wine, the waiter STILL brought us a taste of his selection for free! He did not ask us if we wanted more, he just left it at that! Classy.- the salad & main course, which was a mesclun salad with goat cheese and a yummy dressing. The main course was organic chicken breast with artichoke and some type of mashed potato puree. It was amazing!- they gave us 2 pieces of delicious chocolate at the end for free! Yum.What was whatevers:- the desserts. We got the peach strussel and the sorbet. The sorbet tasted like any 'ol sorbet and it was a bit too expensive for what it was. The streusel was WAY too hard on the bottom and I couldn't even finish it. I felt like I was going to break my fork because it wouldn't penetrate the bottom of the streusel! I could only eat the top.So it was 4 stars, the 1 remaining star would have happened if the desserts were awesome. Desserts are a big deal to me! :)

There's a reason that in a city full of restaurants '21' is one of the most famous and well-regarded. The food is, of course, fantastic and the famous 21 burger is unlike any burger you will ever have. I'm surprised to read that one reviewer didn't feel she was treated well because she was young.... I've never had that experience and I'm in my early 20's. I think you could order water and crackers here and they'd treat you like royalty. Professional to the core, wonderful food, and an atmosphere that is steeped in history, luxury, and old-world, old-money charm.

Went again for Restaurant Week. We had a 9:00 PM reservation, which I had made to celebrate my birthday with my wife and a couple friends. My first experience here was great and I wanted to share that with my friends. It was late on a Thursday night (7/21) but they didn't need to rush lukewarm dishes out to us so they could go home faster. If the service staff had taken a little more time and been a little more friendly, it might have made up a bit for the food, and they would still have gotten home at a reasonable time. Very disappointed.

You come to the 21 club for a sense of history and impeccable service.  We were whisked in our heels and jackets (heels for the girls, jackets for the boys) straight past the historic downstairs and the toy filled bar, to the very private upstairs dining room.  The walls are covered in pastel murals and the fixtures are midcentury modern (most definitely installed when there was no such term).  The service we received from Christopher, our waiter and sommelier was incredibly attentive.  It was restaurant week and between our party of four, we basically sampled the entire special menu.  All the meals were very tasty, but my husband's we all agreed was exceptional.  His meal---Appetizer: mesclun salad with goat cheese crustiniMain: juicy and flavorful chicken dishDessert: a delicate creme bruleeWe topped off the meal with a couple of bottles of rose which made the meal all that more 'rosy'. We will return, next time I think for the 21 burger.

So loved everything about this place.  Can totally imagine it years ago as the speakeasy it was - if only walls, chairs, the bar, and toys (given one at a time by different famous people) could talk.We sat in the Bar room and because I made reservations over the internet, we were greeting with chilled champagne - kinda funny as people at other tables looked at us wondering why we got the champagne....just looked at the promotion on the website...lolApparently, I sat where Humphrey Bogart used to sit.  This was our dinner venue prior to going to a play and I was able to order from the pre-set menu, which for me, was a perfect meal - appetizer, entree, dessert.My boyfriend, being the European that he is, craved the steak tartare and he REALLY enjoyed it!  Me, being the microbiologist that I am, thought E. coli and parasites, and other things you can get from eating raw meat, BUT, the foodie in me said - if it's THAT good for the European, then a bite couldn't hurt me.  (Although technically, it could if the meat was from a bad batch) - so here I was with both sides of my brain weighing the pros and cons.  So the adventurous side won......I actually thought it wasn't bad!  Aside from the texture, the flavor was good and in retrospect, I'm glad I didn't listen to the technical, scientific side of me.....BTW, There is a dress code, so make sure you are appropriately dressed for this place.....Would love to do a historical, behind-the-scenes tour of this place - I hear there are secret, underground spaces......don't know if any are available, but if there are, I missed it, if there isn't - possible business venture???

I had an amazing dinner with my best friend at 21 Club before we went to New Year's Eve 2011 Ball Drop in Times Square. We ate in the Bar Room and the Grilled Organic Chicken Breast was fabulous! The room was a veritable Hall of Fame as a large collection of colorful sports memorabilia and outdoor Christmas decorations. We had plenty of time between courses so that we never felt rushed & were never waiting long for the next course.This is a celebrity hot-spot. I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone wanting to have a fine dining experience in New York around Midtown area.

If it wasn't the 21 club i'd give it 3/3.5 stars, but it's the 21 club, and it's a New York staple so you need to give it at least 4 stars.The food has gotten much better in the last  couple of years. The wine list is extensive, the service is great and the atmosphere (if you want an old school NY place) it's as good as it gets.Great place no doubt, and it's still holding its high standards and reputation.

I had an amazing experience at 21 Club for lunch recently. I'm not sure how accurate my rating of the food can be as we went for Restaurant Week, but it was impressive none-the-less. Immediately when walking in you feel like you've been transported to another era. The decor is regal and whimsical at the same time...there are tiny toy trucks dotting the ceilings and kitschy posters hanging on the walls among dark tapestrys and furniture. My friend and I had a reservation and were seating quickly at a quiet red and white checkered table in the back dining area. The dining areas are dark and cave-like, it would be a very romantic spot for a date. Our waiter brought bread and we ordered our three course lunch. I had:-Chilled Asparagus with watermelon, feta, and olive puree-Grilled pork loin with heirloom grits, butter beans, roasted peach reduction-Vanilla Creme BruleeAll three of my courses were exceptional despite not being on the regular menu. Well cooked, flavorful, and artfully displayed. If the main courses served at 21' are as good as the Restaurant Week ones, I would have no issue highly recommending this place.I can see coming here in the winter to sip a scotch or glass of red wine at the bar with a date or coming back for a fancy meal.

The 21 Club... All the New Yorkers will know what you are talking about when you mention the 21 Club, but what else do they say about besides the décor and it being historically famous? The food? No. The service? No. You would expect them to exception in everything because of their reputation and the price you pay for your meal, but I didn't get ANY of that when I came here with three of my friends for Restaurant Week. Maybe it was because we looked young (every one dining there was over 50 years old) or the fact we didn't order than cocktails to boost our bills. But whatever the reason was, there was absolutely no excuse for them to treat us like crap. Because that is what they EXACTLY did. I was so excited to try the 21 Club. I worked with one of their former managers at the Carlyle Restaurant and he raved about the 21 Club. But little did I know that they don't like college students that were trying to experience good quality food with their low budgets. If you're going to treat every customer that comes in for Restaurant Week like crap, DON'T PARTCIPATE in it. Okay, the host was nice and the décor theme was cool and classic, but it doesn't make up for the 20 minutes we waited for menus and water. And another 15 minutes before we were asked about our order. Then it took a good 15 minutes to even get the check. We had to ask! Many, many times for them to even pay attention to us. I was outraged. I would NEVER go back. Okay, Yelp is about the food... So let's get to that part of the experience. I ordered the grilled calamari to start. It was okay, fancy and yummy. I ate it with the bread basket which was a fantastic array of bread. Yum... My entrée was the salmon atop cous cous with summer fruits and veggies. That was just okay. I wasn't asked how I would like my salmon cooked which was odd to me. But all the same, I was content with my dish. The night ended with  their famous crème brulee and it was my first time trying it. Nothing fantastic. I don't know what all the rave is about. It's just custard. Meh. The food was mediocre at best. I would probably get something like that at anything other restaurant. I wouldn't mind paying for how "okay" the food was if the service made up for it. But since BOTH lacked, I was disappointed and upset with the whole experience and how much I paid... Overall, I WILL NEVER EVER COME BACK. Either for restaurant week or to dine there on just a regular day. Service was literally horrible. They did not live up to their reputation at all. Even if I was offered a comp dinner to mend my horrible experience, I wouldn't even bother. PS. This would have been a one star review, the extra star was for the bread basket. Oh and they require men to wear BLAZERS for dinner and women to be dressed appropriately with heels.

Note: we ate dinner in the upstairs dining room.Upon reading their web site and various reviews, we were aware that the dress was formal.  However, is was not until we got there that we were informed that jackets were required.  As such, we wore house jackets, which was vaguely annoying.The upstairs dining room is quite small, maybe eight tables; the picture on the web site is just about the whole dining room.  The light level is low, as is the noise level.  The space is definitely well maintained, and the decor is early 1960's (think Mad Men).The service was just about the best I have ever had.  The waiter was both knowledgeable, generally very friendly, and easily able to keep up with our sarcastic comments.  We even had various discussions with him, including the history and layout of the building, and about how one becomes a waiter at a high end restaurant.The food was American, with accents.  I had the Filet Mignon, medium rare, and my friends had the Mixed Grill of Game and a fish of the day.  All of the food was excellent: great ingredients, well prepared.  The wine list was excellent, and varied, and the cocktails were prepared correctly.  I had the Chocolate Blackberry Vacherin for dessert, which was absolutely fabulous; I heard the same of the other desserts.What else can I say?  Definitely on par with any other high-end place I have ever eaten (Chez Pannise, French Laundry, Fleur De Lys, Comerc 24).

I enjoy this restaurant every second I walk in. I went years ago and loved it so I went again for my 21st birthday. The decorations on the ceiling are fun to look at and is a definite conversation starter. And the food is amazing! The portions are perfect size. We were able to see the wine cellar in the basement. They told us the history about the restaurant and how the cellar was used during the prohibition. The hidden door was extremely heavy. It was a great experience for my family and I, everyone couldn't stop talking about it.

Was here for an event.The salad was excellent, just a regular tiny salad but it as very fresh with just the right amount of great dressingThe chicken was fabulous, really, chicken!The cheescake was amazing.Servers and staff was excellent!

Don't eat in the restaurant!  Terrible experience with a gelatinous mass called the "Chicken Hash", one of their signature dishes no less.  Only worth going for a cocktail and to say "you've been there"

Went here for a nice dinner with my family and had one of the best dining experiences I've ever had before. The food was fantastic (got the "21" Sirloin), the service was impeccable, and the atmosphere is like none other. This restaurant is certainly expensive, but it's well worth it for the terrific food, and outstanding service. If you're looking for a nice place to bring a client, or want to wow some out of towners with a restaurant they'll never forget, I'd bring them here.

Came here on valentines day weekend. Read the earlier reviews and to be honest with the coin I knew I would drop, I was nervous.  I've been to alot of classic NYC restaurants. Whether it be keanes or the old holmstead or katzs or carnagie.  You come for the experience. The interior of this place is amazing. Between all the chochski on the ceiling and the old school steakhouse waiters gliding around the room. It just oozes classic new york. The menu is basic to a point.  The dry aged sirloin is much like any of the high end steakhouses. But it comes with blue cheese mashed potatoes which were heaven. I ordered the steak tartare of all things and it's was wonderful.  The wine list is extensive and rich with gems.  21 is definitely a special occasion place and perfect for someone looking for a night of old school manhattan class.

This is a New York City iconic legend. Everyone must go here at least once in their life. Jacket is required and I'm glad there are places that exist like this. The history is amazing here and the staff can tell you all about it. The food is good but the waiters are old and tired and need new uniforms. They are old school waiters and have not moved fast in 50 years. They have private dining rooms and one private dining room in particular which is about $500 per person but worth if you have that kind of money to spend. It is a great place to entertain and bring your grandparents. Make sure you have lots of "tipping" cash available because everyone has their hand out but then again who doesn't in NYC. Make sure you have reservations either for dinner or lunch. They are not open on Sundays. You will enjoy this place but not the bill.

Wandered in without knowing the dress code and the host rudely informed us of their jacket dress code and reservation policy. I understand and respect dress codes but as a professional in the hospitality industry I was offended by the rudeness of the host. I don't think it would have been too hard to politely inform us of the policy and invite us back again another night, dressed to their standards. Will not go back, and will warn everyone against this restaurant.

I had the exact opposite experience of Samantha H, who I don't understand could of had such a bad experience there has to be more to this story. When I arrived I had immediate service from a team of waiters. They were quick provide menus and drinks, and happily answered questions about the history of the place. The food was great and I really enjoyed my time there. I would 100% go back as soon as I can.

I just dare you to lose your coat check number.  I was treated like a criminal and forced to TEARS when the man almost refused to let me have my coat because I inverted 2 letters on the difficult to say greek brand name of my coat.  Unacceptable.

What a huge disappointment! We should have known when we arrived this was going to be a bad meal. We were promised the upstairs room when we made our reservation and were seated downstairs. Our waiter told the table next to us the specials but didn't tell us. Our food quality was poor and the waiter told my husband that they have soufflés for dessert (his favorite) but that he couldn't have one because it would take too long.Needless to say, we will never be going back!!Don't believe the hype!!!

For an old, school experience there is no other place to go. At the same time it is very formal (especially when you first walk-in) it is very relaxing in the dinning room. The food is always excellent and the wine list is annually one of the best in the country. If you can, asked for a tour of the famous wine cellar, which is a hidden room where they use to high the booze during prohibition. If you can not make it for dinner, it is a great place to start or finish an evening as the bar is one of the better in a city with great watering holes.

Nice, but just not my cup of tea. While the food was pleasant, the atmosphere was a bit stifling and it seemed like our waiter was trying too hard with the teamCoCo routine to stay relevant and insert himself into our dinner conversation. The saving grace (and third star) is compliments the four bottles of excellent wine we went through. Definitely the highlight of the night. It was nice to try it out and see whether the hype was worth it. Good to see it's not.
I absolutely LOVE the decor!!!!  Like, this is what I want my private library to look like... Amazing service, cutest sommelier ever, good food!

Given the mixed reviews I was apprehensive about booking this place as a pre-Merchant of Venice dining option but I'm glad I did. The menu items weren't anything exotic but they were well executed nonetheless and portions were sizable. And contrary to what I've read about there being "racist/ageist" staff, the service there was top notch to me and my wife --both of us being middle eastern and in our 20s. The maitre d' cheerfully made small talk while we waited for our table to clear, and the coat check and wait staff was very polite and friendly throughout the night. To top it off, we were given complimentary champagne too. Parking was a breeze with a garage situated adjacent to the restaurant. We left relaxed and happy for our 8pm show.

So I am a huge fan of Yelp, use it all the time to help me decide where to go out here in New York and pretty everywhere.  Never felt inclined to open up my own account though....until today.My mother and her friend were in town visiting New York and they made reservations to go to lunch at the 21 Club. Despite the bad things I had heard about the service and decline in food quality I decided to give it a shot with them...Now I know I should really just trust my instincts.We arrived excited to order cocktails, food and have a great time and after checking our coats were immediately confronted with attitude. We sat down and asked for a cocktail list from one person that we never saw again. When the next server came with the menu he dropped it off and we were left to sit for the next ten minutes before we finally had to ask for a server to come and take our drink order.  When I asked for a rye manhattan and kindly asked if he could inform me of the kinds of rye they offered I received a dirty look.  I have to note that the main reason I asked about their selection is because on their cocktail list they offer the "21 Club Perfect Manhattan' "with your choice of rye".  The waiter was not having any of my questions and simply brought me back the perfect manhattan and when i asked what whiskey was used he told me Seagrams 7. I'm sorry but who the hell uses Seagrams seven in a manhattan, especially at fancy pants 21 club.  When I asked to just have a Knob Creek manhattan instead he loudly threw down his serving tray and walked towards the bar. If I hadn't had been with my mom's friend I would have walked out right then.We stayed and had our meals and the food was OK, but after the initial RUDE service the experience for me was completely ruined. Maybe it was a great spot in the past but now I would never recommend it to anyone. Like I said it inspired me to sign up for yelp and spread the word about the horrendous service.

A few friends and I decided that we would try this old school New York place as it was restaurant week and we had heard mixed reviews. From the moment we got there, I fell in love with this place - from the lounge to the decor and the wait staff. The service was impeccable - for starters we had calamari, salmon tartar and the winter greens salad. Each portion was appropriate for an appetizer and each was seasoned very well. My particular favourite was the salmon tartar. Next we had pork belly and the roasted chicken....while the chicken was very good, my particular favourite was the pork belly. It was very tender with a crispy maple flavoured skin. The portion sizes here were surprisingly large for us (only one of us was actually able to finish the entire plate). Finally for dessert we had the lemon meringue tart and the carmel chocolate. Both desserts were great with the lemon meringue being my choice.We had an excellent experience dining here and will definitely be frequenting this place again - I'm glad I finally had a chance to experience this place.

I went for Restaurant Week as a surprise for my boyfriend. It was very old school with dark wood paneling, red seats, and all sorts of little toys on the ceiling. We were excited, but the price fixed menu fell short of my expectations. I started off with the grilled calamari, my boyfriend had the tortilla soup (the daily special), he had the pork belly for his main course and I had the squash risotto, and then for dessert he had the salty chocolate bombe and I had the creme brulee. The tortilla soup was watery and sour... how he ate it is still beyond me. The calamari was rubbery. The pork belly was alright, but more like an upscale bbq. The risotto was way undercooked and sat like a lump. Absolutely awful. Both of the desserts were amazing. Especially the salty chocolate bombe. It was the perfect combination of caramel, salt, and chocolate. The staff was attentive, but they kinda cram the wine list down your throat. We had cocktails to start and didn't order wine. They seemed angry over that. Also you sit almost on top of the people next to you. On our left was a couple who played with their iPads the entire meal, and on your right a couple who were ready to get divorced. If they had been more than a foot away it would have been alright, but given the tight quarters it was awkward. I know this is a NY establishment, but the food wasn't worth the $35. Their menu was lackluster. The desserts were awesome as was the bread, but I'd say pick somewhere else for restaurant week.

yo mama and i came here for restaurant week. yo mama enjoyed the attentive service, but was disappointed with the food and being seated right next to the entrance to the bar room...too much foot traffic for yo mama!

Go knowing it is an old-guard New York place and enjoy the almost kitschy atmosphere and the stellar service.  We were here during Restaurant Week but decided to order off the menu.  Know going in that it is going to be a pricey evening and just enjoy yourself and the wonderful atmosphere of another period in time.  I started with a Manhattan and was actually given the choice of rye or bourbon - most places automatically use bourbon nowadays.  Having a choice was nice as it let me know that the waitstaff paid attention to detail and knew their stuff.  We started with one of our mainstays, carpaccio.  21 club specifically offers a grass-fed beef carpaccio dressed with rocket (arugula), 'Cipriani' sauce, deviled quail egg, Parmesan and truffle oil.  To be honest, I wasn't wowed with the carpaccio.  It tasted a little flat, even with the sharpness of the arugula, possibly due to the Cipriani sauce which tasted largely like plain mayo.  The quail egg was a nice touch.Next, we enjoyed sauteed Dover sole with Champagne sauce.  It was spectacular: perfectly cooked and the Champagne sauce was so delicious that I wanted to lick the plate.  I'd go back just for the sole.I ordered a double espresso in lieu of dessert and it was quite good as well.  Not somewhere that I'd frequent on a regular basis, the 21 Club is still a great venue for special occasions or when you want the charm of its unique atmosphere.

21 club is pretty much old school atmosphere. The bar/restaurant is dark, with red seats, and red kitchen-table cloth on dark wood tables. Various items, ranging from airplanes, teddy bears, to other kitsch hanging from the ceiling. There were about six waiters serving us for a restaurant week dinner. Somewhat confusing.The service was pretty prompt. We had the salmon tartar, calamari, the main course salmon, pork belly, and velvet cake and lemon merengue for desert. The tartar was tiny, but good, with it's zesty horseradish decoration. Calamari was ok, nothing to speak of. Salmon was ok as well, but how much can you really mess up when grilling a salmon...it had a bed of grain mixed with carrots. The pork belly was good, a bit on the fatty side. My merengue was bad, odd mix of clunky sugars with sugary lemon underneath. I didn't even finish it. The velvet cake was equally sugary, but a bit more agreeable.When i ordered a second glass of wine, the waiter suggested a chianti, which i liked, but turned out to be $19. A bit much for the DOC taste of Tuscany. Same for $5.50 for an espresso.Bottom line: Underwhelming in terms of food. If you like old school atmosphere, go there for a drink and maybe appetizers, and save you money for a real good restaurant somewhere else.

Went to the famous 21 Club this past Friday for Restaurant Week in the Bar Room. The interior was very cute and old fashioned.  I was intrigued by the cars, trucks and helmets hanging from the ceiling in the Bar Room but it was pretty cute. The seating is very intimate. We had a table of 6 but were very close to one another but not crowded either. The light shined right in the middle of our round table. The Kennedys and Ronald Reagan sat in the same table we did.Our waiter was very nice and friendly. We ordered a bottle of riesling, which never disappoints. For the food, I ordered the salmon tartare as the appetizer, which was really fresh. My other friends ordered the grilled calamari, which wasn't bad either. As for the entree, I ordered the seared chicken breast. The skin was the best part bc it was peppery and the chicken was pretty moist. My friends ordered the pork belly, which looked really fatty to me but they liked it. The desserts here were pretty disappointing. I got the Lemon Meringue Tart and it was too sweet/sour. I know it sounds weird but I can't explain it any other way. Everytime I took a bite out of it, I had a sour face on after. It was very difficult to enjoy and eat the tart. I'm not big on desserts either and I dont have a sweet tooth, so that's something to keep in mind as well. My boyfriend for the red velvet cake and that was too sweet for me too. My other friend got the creme brulee and I'm not really a fan of creme brulee either. Overall, the restaurant was very cute and the food was okay. This restaurant is kind of overhyped in my opinion but it's not terrible either. It was fun to try it.

Sat in the bar, had delicious food a great cocktail and wine with dinner.  Service was fantastic, wait staff from host, wine steward and bus person were perfect.  Had the pre fixe Restuarant Week special.  It is crowded and noisy in the bar, so not the right room for a romantic dinner but perfect for unwinding after a long day.

My fiance wanted our engagement dinner to be very special so he took me to the 21 Club.I was very excited about going to the "famous" 21 Club.It was one of the best dinners I have ever had in my life.The bread basket that was served had the most unique breads. There was one that I was very addicted to. I could have eaten the bread all night.Our appetizers were oysters, that were fabulous!The wine we selected was a Chilean wine that was superb.We had both decided on the filet mignon as our main course.This is by far the best filet mignon I have ever tasted. We finished up with sorbet for dessert, which was delicious.This establishment maybe expensive, but your stomach will thank you.

I can't believe how pretentious this restaurant is and how angry I am at myself for wasting my money here. First of, the food was terrible and secondly, the waiter was hovering around my table the whole night, grabbing my plate as soon as I was close to finishing.  IT WASN'T EVEN BUSY. So I don't understand why they were in such a hurry to get my party out of there. Don't go here, save your money.

Just had my company's holiday party at the famous 21 club. We rented out the wine cellar and had the 7 course wine pairing menu.  The venue deserves 5 stars as does the fantastic service. However for $450/person we left a bit underwhelmed by the food when we expected an amazing culinary experience. The veal Wellington was over cooked with flat puffed pastry that was falling off the meat and the chocolate soufflé was also totally overcooked as well. Can't stress enough what a fun evening it was to be in such an incredible venue with such terrific service but still can't give more than 3 stars when we paid so much for such mediocre food.

Quite simply the best restaurant in all of NYC and beyond (in my opinion). After having read about its history, and watching it on TV shows, I just had to come here. My fiance and I were moving back to Long Island in June 2010 so we decided to celebrate our bon voyage by coming here. We had reservations on a Saturday night during Restaurant Week. We tried to order different things so we could sample each others food. Bread basket was delicious. Food was excellent. The dishes were timed enough apart that we were never rushed but we weren't left waiting either. Waiter service is commendable! Every waiter pays attention to detail. They answered all of my questions, and were there in a heartbeat to move the table for me when I had to get up. I received a complimentary glass of wine. At the end of our first visit I had asked to speak with a manager about possibly getting a tour of the downstairs famed wine cellar. He told me that there was a party downstairs. About 5 minutes later he came back and said they were finishing up and if I waited around I could the tour. I was ecstatic! One of the workers there showed my fiance and myself around and took pictures of us. We weren't rushed and all of our questions were answered. What a peeeeeeerfect way to end the night!---We came back here before Restaurant Week ended in October to celebrate our 7 year anniversary. When ordering the waiter heard me whisper to my fiance that we should get different desserts than last time even though creme brulee is our favorite and we had it already. He was nice enough to bring us all 3 dessert choices! He also noticed that I was reading a card and came over to ask the occassion. When we told him, he gave us complimentary champagne to toast. (I also was served a complimentary glass of wine during the meal.) It was a wonderful evening. We couldn't ask for better service or food.

Best cheesecake in NYC besides Juniors.  This is a classic, elegant restaurant in the heart of the city.  I spent many nights here with my ex-bf dining (probably the best part of our relationship).  I loved the salmon dishes, the chateau-briand and caesar salad.  This is a "must:, just for the ambiance alone.

Very classic New York City. The driver of our cab got very excited when we told him where we were headed. "You guys rich or something?" Haha no, just a nice dinner paid for by my girl friends parents ;)Drinks: Mumm champagne, And a really yummy white I cannot remember the name of. VERY tasty.Starter: Cesar Salad, might have easily been the best one I've EVER eaten. Licked my plate clean. Ah-may-zing.Meal: Dover Sole, also exquisite. The champagne sauce was delicious and it was served with some yummy seasonal veggies. Dessert: Cheesecake, might have been the best cheesecake I've ever eaten... and that's saying alot, because I LOVE cheesecake. While this meal definitely was not cheap, it was nice dressing up and going out for a fabulous meal in a famous restaurant...

Well hello classic NY. Please let me note in advance that the two stars are for my 1) company I was with because it was a special occasion and I love him 2) The two parties sitting next to us that provided entertainment all night. (hilarious characters and funny conversations). Basically the atmosphere.  The End. We had obvisouly heard of the 21 Club and knew all of its history. We came in with a lot of expectations. The shortcomings that led to my "Meh" experience. 1) Poor service. Yes, there were at any given time about 4 different people helping our table but at about 20 minutes in between and nobody seemed to know who was our server, what we wanted, what we were waiting for etc. 2) The server didnt know what an "Old Fashioned" was. Came back and said the bartender had not made this drink for over 10 years. Oh and there was also a fly in the glass. So, they made it twice that night. Ew. Also, wasnt taken off the bill for the EW situation. My martini was good. 3) Food was good but nothing great. The food wouldnt take us back there again. Had the risotto and the Steak tartar. The oysters were good but we ordered 4 and they only brought out 3. Weird. Coffee was good. I am glad I had a chance to see the restaurant with all the history on the walls and decorations on the ceilings but wouldnt venture here again. Seems like it has lost its charm. Also, upstairs seems to be for families as a million kids were running up and down the stairs all night.

I was not expecting much from this place, as I thought it probably traded on its reputation. Truth be told, the food was quite good, and the service attentive. And it is a real trip to eat in such a landmark, to think about all of the famous people that have dined there.   If the menu were a bit more adventurous, it would have rated 4 stars.

A group of 3 of us came here for dinner during Restaurant Week and we each ordered different items on the menu so we could get a little taste of everything.  Was sort of awkward trying to share some of the smaller items, though.The bread basket came out promptly and it came with so many varieties of bread and crackers and they were all good. For the appetizers, we got the citrus and juniper-cured mahi mahi, wild game terrine, and the potato leek soup.  The terrine came with this really good horseradish/mustard.  I also liked the mahi mahi and the soup was pretty good, sort of standard.For the main course, we ordered the wild mushroom risotto, coffee-chili rubbed pork chop, and the horseradish-crusted salmon.  My favorite was the pork chop and we all agreed. The risotto was pretty good too.  I don't remember the salmon very well, though.  Guess it was just okay for me.I really liked the desserts here.  We had the pear tart, vanilla bean creme brulee, and the dark chocolate moussecake.  My personal favorite was the moussecake because I love chocolate, but the overall winner of the night was the creme brulee.We thoroughly enjoyed our meal.  The service was good, ambiance was nice, gave us an excuse to dress up and we had a chance to try something new.

It's clear to me that I've travelled and that I'm a seasoned eater. Well really, what did you think. Club 21 is good and is caters to the business pre-elite of NYC visitors. No respectful NYC resident actually eats at Club 21 unless they're over the age of 65 and from Yonkers. The upstairs is apparently great but I ended-up sitting downstairs amongst the kitch hanging from the ceiling. The have a great wine selection and the food is good. The staff is friendly and make the entourage that much better.

I've been wanting to go here for sometime now and finally got the chance to do so this past Friday. We had reservations so we were promptly seated. I surveyed the crowd, which definitely consisted of people way older than me, I'm 25. The restaurant is dimly lit and the ceiling is decorated with toy trucks and other miscellaneous toys. The place was a little chilly. I went there for lunch and participated in their restaurant menu which is till the end of October. Here was what I ordered: Appetizer: Butternut squash soup with lobster - probably the best butternut squash soup I've had so far. It was creamy and delicious. However, the waiter had made a mistake and it actually would not be garnished with lobster but he brought us a small dish of lobster meat anyway which was nice. Entree: Horseradish crusted salmon - I had it cooked medium well and it was still moist and very tasty. I'm not a fan of horseradish and didn't really taste it on the salmon, I just scraped it off the top of the fish. I didn't except to get full with this meal but the salmon was quite filling. Dessert: Vanilla bean creme brulee - absolutely delicious, definitely tingled my taste buds and hit the spot. It was made really well and the crusted layer was yummy. Service was alright, it wasn't prompt but staff were attentive enough. Overall, I enjoyed it and would recommend it, especially if you are participating in their restaurant week menu. The regular menu is pricey.

I'd give it 4.5 Stars if I could.I think the service here is spectacular. You have to come here knowing that you're going to be spending some money. You will have several waiters and staff attending to your service. They clearly have a good communication system going on. Everywhere you go in here, you will have someone helping you do something (sit down, bathroom..., choosing what to eat, etc). Expect some extra $ to be going out for tip. Friend and I had the pre-fixe menu for restaurant week ($35) - ends Oct 31 (so go now)! Had the fried calamari for appetizer. It was well-cooked and  zesty (lemon). My friend had the cured salmon and that was also good (and interesting). I've never had cured salmon that came in cubes, but it was good. My main dish was the pork belly. It was very good, but I did feel like I ended up eating a lot of fat. It comes with a little bit of braised pork on the bottom, and a few cuts of carrot. I felt like it was a little on the meaty side w/o any vegetables, but it was still decent.Dessert- had the almond plum tart. Really good - highly recommend it.The night was full of random complimentary dishes/snacks/drinks. This restaurant is one of NYC's few old-fashioned high-class restaurants. Very nice interior with a lot of interesting artifacts hanging on the wall. Bathroom was very clean and has someone serving you the whole time. Good place to go. Highly recommend it for a special night out.

Popped in here before the theatre, which seems to be what a lot of people do. Got the Theatre Prix Fixe, I think it was $35. I honestly had to check their menu to remember what I had, guess it wasn't that memorable, but I do remember enjoying it (had the salmon).The place is cute -very Mad Men, I ended up getting a martini cuz I just felt I had to.A bit busy -I'd say more of a fun place to go than a romantic meal.

Yum!Came here during restaurant week and ate off of the prix-fixe menu. Three of us went, so we were able to get good combinations of the appetizers, entrées, and desserts and try a little of everything.There's a strict dress code, which gives you a nice little excuse to get fancy and pretty for the night; something not everyone enjoys, but I do!There are a bunch of lawn jockeys decorating the outside. Inside, there's a v. baroque feel, with mauves and mahogany and gilded mirrors. (Just an aside, the bathrooms are really cute, or at least the ladies' restroom is).The food wasn't explosively fantastic or anything, but it was quite delicious. We all agreed we were pretty satisfied.

Took an out-of-town guest here to get a feel for that Old New York glamor. It was such fun--and the majority of that was related to the ambiance and atmosphere.The dress code is non-negotiable--gentlemen must wear jackets, and jeans are not permitted. (My guest got some funny looks for failing to wear a tie.) Women were only recently permitted to wear pants. Embrace it! Get all dressed up for a night on the town.Inside, you'll find all kind of relics of Old NYC--from the antique toy airplanes suspended from the ceiling, to the dishes and cocktails, to your fellow patrons. It's true, the crowd tends to be on the older side, and it's quite formal. There are many servers, so it can get crowded and confusing. Order from the restaurant week menu if it's available (but don't get the pork chop), or go nuts off of the regular one. They have a large wine list for under $60, and the sommelier is unbelievable; don't hesitate to ask him for advice. All of the cocktails we tasted were great, too.The seating is tight, so make friends with your neighbors. We wound up sharing a glass of port over dessert with the folks closest to us. The whole night was like entering an era from long before we were born, and it was just lovely to reenact some of the legendary stories you heart about. Would definitely return on a special occasion for the same sort of fun.

I ordered the dinner prix fixe and it wasn't that great because I was limited on options. I had the seasonal soup, which was watermelon soup. It was refreshing; the texture is the same as tomato soup. For my entrée, I didn't enjoy it much. I had a dish called Spring Vegetable Risotto, which tasted like melted cheese with rice and some mixed vegetables. It reminded me of mac and cheese except it was with white cheese and with rice and the cheese was soupy. As for my dessert, I had the Vanilla Bean Crème Brûlée. I tried many before and this wasn't that great; the taste was heavy on eggs, meanwhile, it was suppose to be vanilla bean flavored. On the other hand, my friends enjoyed their meat and fish dishes. The environment is quite dark that the employees each carried their own little mini flashlight to read orders; I found that a little humorous. I think the private dining area would have been a better experience.

One of my favorite places in New York. The menu is excellent, with something for everyone. Especially like the Steak Tartare but also had a great sea bass dish over spinach. Be sure to ask for the cheese toasts (called 21 toasts) - not on the menu - but excellent.I find the ambience fun and the staff helpful. Even though it always seems busy - never had to wait to get someone's attention. This is a mainstay on my list and I always look for an excuse to drop in.

could be 4. I went to this place during the summer restaurant week and maybe some of the cons here can be due to the busy resto week circumstance. The service is not friendly, but decent, attentive. But I didn't feel anything luxurious or fancy or exciting or comfortable or amazed or amused(Their famous decor of hanging toys can be amusing though). Food is OK, but nothing special. I was a little surprised with the old fashioned banal appetizer calamari. Pork belly was pretty good, but nothing fancy or remarkable. The most surprising part was their seating. We were seated next to each other on the sofa side at a TEENY TINY table just like the disney movie "Lady and the Tramp" (2 doggies' love story thing).Maybe still fan experience to dine in their famous bar room, if you can go there during the restaurant week with the reasonable price. But kinda skeptical if you can still stay happy eating there with their regular price.

As noted in my earlier review - for the baptism lunch, the shower, the anniversary, the business lunch with out-of-town guests, it is one of those places people go.  Not sure it would be on my list for a Friday night dinner with friends, but I have enjoyed the atmosphere, service, and food every time I have been there.I did recently have the pleasure of utilizing the private dining room in the wine cellar for a retirement lunch with around 15 people....through the kitchen...behind the hidden wall....through racks of private wine stocks (belonging to Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Nixon, and Chelsea Clinton to name a few)..and over the threshold down into the sunken, softly lit dining room.  A different (more regal/formal-jackets required I believe) feel than the private dining area in the wine cellar at Aroma Kitchen & Wine Bar (softer, more rugged) that I have grown to love, but the experience was totally outstanding.  The food was absolutely incredible, the service impeccable, and the atmosphere totally unique and interesting.  I would recommend it highly for any dressed-up group gathering for sure.

The Bad- Environment (dark--the waitors had their own mini flashlights to read people's orders; squishy--everyone was like cramped over each other; the ceiling ordaments might fall on you )- Was sat near the cart with sauces and etc.- Rushed throughout the meal (our dessert was on the cart right next to us meanwhile we were still eating our entree)- Spring Vegetable Risotto (good if you enjoy hot cereal)- Milk Chocolate Tart (big marshmellow right on top of tart)- Waitor took the bread basket away even if we didn't finish yet (was taken away before we finished our entree)The Good- Smoked Pork Belly (friend said it was really good but the fat part of it looked unappetizing to me; however, the pork belly sat on top of some shredded pork, which was fantastic)- Horseradish-Crusted Salmon (nothing that amazing but not that bad either---just your typical salmon dish)- Cured Mahi Mahi (good but nothing special to remember)- Bread basket (so many types)The Bottomline- Not worth checking out. This place was nothing spectaluar. I expected so much better from the reviews that I have read. You can waste your money here for decent food. Hopefully you don't slip on their floor on the way to the bathroom or trip over a little kid since it's so dark there.
It is always nice to visit the 21 Club for me whenever I can. 21 Club is partof the restaurant week. As usual the meal was awesome and you can't beat the special price at $24.07.

Loved it. Came here for restaurant week. Firstly dress code. Gentlemen must wear jackets, my friend tried to remove his when sitting down but you must wear your jacket once step in, you cannot remove it! For dinner, ties are recommended. No jeans or sneakers. Even the waiters had bow ties and jackets, which made them look like businessmen from behind, so make sure you talk to the right person when you need something.Food was excellent!Bread basket: sesame buns, crispy raisin bread slices, others. Appetizer: gazpacho soup. Delicious, thick and creamy, not too cold.Main course: salmon. Watch out, the sauce on top tastes like wasabi so it was a tiny bit spicy. Salmon was very soft, not overcooked at all.Desert: creme brulee with cookies. The cookie was soft and delicious. The creme brulee had a nice caramel hard caramel shell layer on top, and below was the soft custard. I never liked creme brulee but I think I do like this one, I must have been eating crappy creme brulee growing up.

Food was good and service was impeccable. It's certainly a classic New York spot, you feel it when the moment you walk in. You'll see vintage toy cars, helmets hanging on the ceiling which we all found it very unique and intriguing. Please remember that dress code is required in this restaurant. (In which means no jeans, snickers.)  It's extremely expensive, but worth the treat for a special occasion. We're all very glad that there's restaurant week. So we can have pre-fix menu with a set price and great food.

Restaurant Week Summer 2010 in the bar room. Another stop on our "classic, old school NYC" tour. Service was very friendly and attentive. We were greeted about 5 times on the way in and thanked about 5 times on the way out. The only thing with having multiple servers is you never really interacted with any of them. When it was time for our check we weren't even sure who was ours! I felt a little rushed in that the minute our salad was cleared our main course arrived and the minute that disappeared the dessert was brought. It was like they had it lined up for a quick turnover. However after our dessert they didn't try to rush us out, so maybe their timing just was a bit quick. Overall good service though. For restaurant week I had the salad, spring vegetable risotto, and the creme brulee. The salad was nothing special. The risotto was good, had a good strong parmesan taste. Only complaint is it seemed like it had sat for a few minutes before serving, could have been hotter. The creme brulee was the best part of the meal and was excellent. Overall it was a nice meal. Its not a place I would go back to if I were choosing but I enjoyed being able to check another classic NYC restaurant off the list.

Okay, I get that this place is famous and all but it just wasn't good!  The clientele were a few business diners with clients and tourists.  Jacket required and it was dang hot in there.  Needless to say, my dining partner was not thrilled.  It cost $20 for a TINY house salad.  The pieces of lettuce (only four) were too big so they had to be cut up.  There were a few parmesan cheese shavings on the plate and a vinaigrette dressing that was just okay.  For dinner the salmon was alright.  Definitely nothing to write home about.  The sole was listed as "market price".  I had never seen that before for flounder but hey...maybe I'm just not sophisticated enough for this place.  The service actually sucked for having like 8 different people wait on you.  I had to flag down a waiter at least twice to place an order or ask for other things.  Definitely not the flawless execution you'd expect from a place like this.  THANK GOODNESS I did not pick up the tab.  If I had even glanced at it I might have keeled over.

SO EXCITED TO GO TO THIS RESTAURANT because of reviews etc, and suppose to be a NY classic, BOYYYYYYYYYYY was I wrong, well the decor was perfect, everything started out really good, even the host was very nice etc...then once we sat down everything went down hill, our waiter seemed like we were more then a bother then anything else, we were asking abou the restaurant about the decorations etc, and he seemed so bothered to tell us, maybe he was having a bad day, so i got a free drink because i rsvp throught there website, and he didnt seem to happy, I was here with my 13 yr old daughter and we were decked out for this evening, I saw how happy etc they were serving the groups etc around us, im a 40% or more type of tipper I dont ask for much.... so then we waited about 12 minutes before anyone came to ask us to order apps or something a waiter next to us saw us watinin and came and took order, so we ordered our food,,,, uggghhhh i ordered the pork taste like it wa dipped in bacon grease, the side tasted like it was marinated in it never seen so much fat left on the pork chop , my daughter ordered salad, which was basic, nothing different then a deli salad, the miso soup was actually pretty good, then by that time i was livid no body came to check on us and they were helping person next to us just not us, then we ordered the creme brulee which was actually superb.... but waited again, and agin for check oh and my daughter ice in drink was melted and then they poured the coke into water down ice disgusting..... i was ready to get the fu#$# out of there, i hated it, so then nicly asked to speak with mngr just to express my feelings, he couldnt even give a shi# i guess since he i just a manager at a restuarant.. he was a joke, that place was a joke... i will not go back or recommend, many people told me not to go but i did, i rather give the money i spent on the hot dog stand down the street, .........

BEWARE! Restaurant week menus are not as advertised and you will be charged.  My husband and I were looking forward to spending a great evening here celebrating my birthday.  But, the restaurant week menu (because who is going to pay their regular prices for mediocre food) that is displayed on their web site isn't what is presented in person.  So, we quietly told our server that we weren't interested in dining since they were not serving the main dishes we were interested in having.  I get my credit card bill today and was charged $50 because we left.  I talked to the manager and that is their policy, unbelievable.  People there are way to many outstanding restaurants in New York to waste your time here.  A definite tourist trap.

The 21 club is a must do.  Its one of those places that is so new york and must be experienced at least once.  The charm and old world of this restaurant is hard to come by.  We enjoyed the pre theatre dinner and had steak with a wonderfu light salad as a starter. The entree was accompanied by a wonderful mash of sweet potatoes and a delicious red wine sauce. Couldnt have asked for a better meal and better ambiance.

old money type kindda place. We were the youngest people there, a little stuffy but bearable. Excellent service though, Food were unimpressive, my salmon was a little dry but still edible. My salad was bad, all stale and dressing was just wrong. I'm a foodie so even though service was awesome, food just didn't make it.

BRUTAL.Had some drinks here about a year ago, loved the "Old School" feel although most of the patrons had gone to school in the mid 1800s, and wanted to try dinner........so......Sometimes you get what you ask for....and it SUCKS. We actually made the mistake of taking a customer here for dinner. We sat and had an enjoyable few drinks before he showed and our waitress was great.After he arrived the three of us were seated. The dinning room was approximately 80% full, and I was the youngest one there by about 100 years......the service from Team 6 was THE WORST in 2010 so far. I really think they forgot about us several times, perhaps they were so old they couldn't see us......Food = HORRIBLE....I am pretty sure the City was short a few rats after we ate. I had the Sirloin the server recommended and it was BAD. I also had the Cheesecake and it was pretty good, and they must have sensed how much we hated it because we got a "free" petit fours and moosecake.DON'T GO HERE --- EVER.3 Tanqueray 38.251 Absolut Juice 12.251 Makers Mark 11.751 Gr Octopus 22.001 Sambucca 12.502 Jameson 22.50 (why do I do this to myself?)1 Cabernet 10.002 Sirloin 92.00 (HORRIBLE)1 RW Chicken 35.001 Apple Crumb 10.501 Cheesecake 10.503 Comp Petit Fours 0.001 RW Moussecake 0.00Food - 170.00Liquor - 97.25Wine - 10.00Total - $301.86

I would consider 21 Club as one of my favorite places to wine and dine.  Not simply for the food and/or decor, but mainly for the complete experience.  Everybody is dressed like they're attending the most exclusive party.  I felt the amount of effort people put in just to dine at this place.We were seated at the bar area, but wish we were at the dining room upstairs instead.  The bar area was fine with plenty to gawk at, particularly the random plane models and figurines hanging from the ceiling.  My first impression after being seated at our table was something like T.G.I. Friday's poor efforts of going upscale by making their waiters dress in cheap penguin suits.  Other than that, the place felt toppled with very rich history in a comfortable, homey way.The food was great and is what distinguishes it from T.G.I. Friday's.  We thoroughly enjoyed our meal and it was a fine experience.Service felt like I was back at home in NJ... and this feeling is not necessarily a good thing... I think T.G.I. Friday's tops it in that area, but I could tell they tried to accommodate even though they were extremely busy that night... so + for effort.Among the most memorable experiences that night was in the men's bathroom.  I had a brief conversation with the charismatic bathroom attendant, who has worked throughout 21 Club's rich history.  He has enthusiastically talked about meeting some prominent figures in the bathroom including all the Presidents since Nixon except Bush Jr.  He was going on with a list of celebrities and powerful people he's met in his workplace.  After going on and on about all the important people he's met, I've ended the conversation with, "well, now you've met me."

I've been to 21 twice - once in the Upstairs Dining Room and once in the Bar Room.  The Upstairs Dining Room is an experience that I think everyone should try once.  We were basically in a room with four other tables and with more or less a personal server.The Bar Room is a fun experience as this is where all the action is.  Celebrations, Birthdays, Anniversary's, you name it, it's going on - most of which are of the retirement, 75th or 50th variety.The food is very comfortable and classic.  I love the tar tar and have enjoyed the fish dishes.  You pay a couple extra bucks for great service that Shaker and Co. bring, but it's a great experience and I recommend it to everyone .  I love this place!

Disappointed.  I went over the weekend with 4 friends.  Three of us ordered from the fixed price menu.  Two of us got the Asparagus Soup and Coffee-Chili Rubbed Pork Chop.  One of the chops had a bone - one didn't.  I thought that was a little strange.  The soup was flavorless.  The pork chop tasted good but it did NOT  taste "Coffee-Chili Rubbed" in the least.  The whipped potatoes tasted like they came from a box.  The spinach was delicious but it was the only really good thing I tasted there.  One person got the Creamy Chicken Hash - that looked like they dumped a can of cream of chicken soup on the plate - it tasted OK - nothing to rave about.  Another person go the Steak Tar-tare.  That looked so bad I didn't even try it.  But, my friend said it was OK - not what she expected.  It took a long time to get our entrees.   I got the pear tart for dessert.  It tasted like they got it at Costco.  Yes, the wine list was very extensive; and the waitstaff was attentive.  They filled our water glasses over and over.  And they even walked outside to direct us to the theater that we were going to.  But for the money - it was NOT WORTH IT.  I would not go there again.

I was disappointed in the 21 Club.  I've heard so much about it, but the restaurant week menu I tried was subpar.  The sad thing was that they did not have any of their entrees on the restaurant week menu.  I understand if a restaurant puts their cheapest item on the RW menu.  But to put something that's not even on the menu?  Poor form.Anyway, the food was actually below average.  Maybe I'll try the 21 Club again on a bigger budget, but I don't know if it's worth it.

I don't have much to add here.  21 Club is stunning and the environment is high powered/old world cool.  It really is an NYC gem.  But the food is just meh and not worth the price.  Go for fun once but don't expect anything more than a cultural landmark with exceptional service and decent food that is way overpriced.

It's one of the mandatory experiences that are overrated.  The decor and speakeasy is a must see.  The food is what you'd get at a large banquet hall in New Jersey, it's just average and slightly disappointing.  The yelp 3 star of "A-OK" sums it up nicely.
